speechtext:
Hon. members will remember that several days ago, the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier and others rose with regard to the release of a document by the Commissioner of Official Languages which was given under embargo to members of the media, but through an error in his office it was not made available to members of Parliament.
The hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier raised the matter as a question of privilege, but out of courtesy to a very distinguished Canadian and an officer of this place, pointedly refrained from moving the motion. As a consequence, of course, he relieved me from the obligation of having to decide whether there was or was not in fact a prima facie case of privilege.
Other members in the Chamber who spoke made it clear that what had happened was not acceptable, but it was very clear also that an explanation was hoped for which would satisfy the House.
I undertook to return to the House on this matter.
I wish to advise hon. members that the Commissioner of Official Languages telephoned me later on that day and indicated to me that, whatever had happened, he had to take and did take absolute responsibility for it, that it was an error, and that he was deeply concerned and deeply apologetic. I indicated to him that I would transfer that message to the House.
I received a letter dated May 7 and I wish to read it into the record:

Hon. John Fraser Speaker of the House of Commons Parliament Buildings Wellington Street Room 222-N Ottawa, Ontario K1A 0A6 Dear Sir:
On May 5, 1992, a mistake was made for which I take full responsibility. It was certainly due to the usual tension that accompanies the submission of the first annual report by a new Commissioner. However, the members who raised a question of privilege in this respect were right to do so, and I wish to extend my sincere apologies to all members of the House of Commons.
Yours very truly,
Victor C. Goldbloom LE Commissioner of Official Languages [English]
I should also advise the House that the Commissioner was in touch with our Clerk. I will, I am sure, be able to report back to the commissioner that we accept his regrets and that we wish him well in the continued duty, not just to this House but to the country, for which he has a very fine reputation.

That this House has no confidence in the government because of its abject failure to provide job training and retraining initiatives to enable Canadians to cope with the economic dislocations and deprivations resulting from federal government policies; and, in particular,
That this House condemn the Minister of Employment and Immigration for his continual failures to provide the House and the people with accurate and unambiguous factual information in this matter.
He said: Madam Speaker, Canadians might under ordinary circumstances take heart in the fact that today the unemployment figures dropped from 11.1 per cent of the work force to 11 per cent.

May 8, 1992
Supply
When you examine those figures, however, the decline of the numbers of people on unemployment insurance by 14,000 was more than offset by the 71,000 increase in Canadians who have given up looking for a job. They dropped out of the work force because they have been trying for weeks and months to find jobs but just cannot.
We cannot take heart from this so-called decline in unemployment because it shows by people dropping out of the work force how desperate people have become. What does this mean? Not getting unemployment insurance, we are transferring them to the welfare rolls of the provinces and the cities. More and more people today are on the welfare rolls.
This is a sad legacy of a government that has committed itself to economic growth, stimulating the economy, getting it going. Its economic programs have been an abject failure.
Today I want to talk about one of the government's so-called policies or programs that was designed to make Canada's economy strong.
Everybody, be it in the government, the opposition or the experts outside, will say that without training, research development, education, science and technology, Canada's economic future will be even more dismal than it is at present. Training, admittedly by the government, is one of its key strategies for meeting the competitive challenge for Canada.
This government has boasted that there have been monumental increases in training. It cites its Bill C-21, which changed the unemployment insurance program, as the hallmark and the start of its program for training. I would like to quote the Minister of Employment and Immigration who said in this House on April 30 of this year: "What we have obtained amounts to $400 million more that will be spent to train individual Canadians who become unemployed this year".
He made a blanket and categorical statement that this government has increased funding for training by $400 million this year. Let us look at the government's own figures as obtained from the estimates.
The federal initiative for job training comes under two heads, Canadian Jobs Strategy and unemployment insurance. Let us look at the Canadian Jobs Strategy program first of all. The estimates show that rather than increasing this year, the Canadian Jobs Strategy funding for training has fallen by $114 million. If you look at the benchmark here of 1989-90, four years ago, funding for training under the Canadian Jobs Strategy program has actually fallen by $217 million per year, with a cumulative decline of over $300 million from that benchmark year. So much for the government's program for training.
Let us look at the second one, unemployment insurance. Yes, there has been an increase in the unemployment insurance category for training. This year, if you take one figure, it is up $95 million over last year, giving the government the benefit of the doubt. If you take out the $75 million that relates to entrepreneurs, it is only a $20 million increase out of unemployment insurance this year for training. This figure over the four-year base period has gone up from zero, a zero component for training out of unemployment insurance in 1989-90, to $500 million this year.
During that period what has happened? The government privatized unemployment insurance. It is no longer a fund to which the government contributes. It is strictly an insurance fund paid for 60 per cent by employers and 40 per cent by workers. So the government is not contributing to this fund. It backed out of its 25 per cent commitment.
In addition, when it privatized unemployment insurance so that it falls entirely on the backs of employers and workers, the Minister of Finance made a commitment in this House that he would not for three years increase unemployment insurance premiums. What have we seen instead? We have seen two increases in premiums which amount to a 31 per cent increase in the unemployment insurance premiums.
What we have seen over all is a government that has cut its contribution to training under the Canadian Jobs Strategy by $217 million. We have seen an increase in the training component paid for by our workers and employees. What this amounts to is this government is picking the pockets of our employers and employees in order to cope with the desperate economic circum-

stances which are the direct result of this government's economic mismanagement and incompetence.
Now let me look just a little further at some of these figures. The Minister of Employment and Immigration, as I stated earlier, has said categorically that funding for training has gone up this year by $400 million.
When looking at the over-all figures, the unemployment insurance aspect of training has gone up from $1,498 billion to $1.8 billion. If this is the figure he is referring to, this is not a $400 million increase; it is a $302 million increase, so his arithmetic is way off.
If he is trying to hoodwink Canadians into thinking that that full $1.8 billion is going to training, let us look at his own figures. Is job sharing to which $100 million goes a training program? No. Is a job creation program to which $120 million goes a training program? No. Is a program of $75 million for the self-employed a training program? No. Is an income support program during transition of about $1 billion a training program? No. That is simply the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to people who are on a training program. If they were not taking the training program, that money would still have to be paid out as regular unemployment insurance benefits.
So what we found under the government's own estimates is the allocation out of the $1.8 billion that goes to training courses is only $500 million this year; $500 million which, as we have said, comes wholly and completely out of the pockets of employers and employees.
I repeat, the government at the same time has cut back its funding under its own program, the Canadian Jobs Strategy.
But the government is going to ask: "But is it not right that workers and employers should fund all of this training, should fund all of the unemployment insurance out of their own pockets?" That might be an argument if the government were not a major player in creating conditions of employment and unemployment.
When this government privatized unemployment insurance, the unemployment level in Canada was 7.5 per cent. In the four years since then it has gone up to 11 per cent. There are 493,000 more unemployed Canadians.

That is not because it is their fault, as this government is always saying. It is not because the private sector is not necessarily doing its share of training. It is not because our Canadian workers do not know how to work. It is not because they are not willing to work; it is because they have been saddled with economic policies propagated by this government that have deliberately, by the government's own admission, created a recession in Canada.
The government created a recession in Canada long before the Americans thought of going into a recession. The government was so preoccupied with its high interest, high dollar, high tax policies at the same time it brought in free trade that it made it almost impossible for all but a few Canadian companies to compete, to grow, to expand.
The level of the dollar alone from the time the free trade talks started until free trade came in and last year had gone up 27 per cent. That is a 27 per cent penalty against Canadian manufacturers that were going to be exporting to the United States. Can you tell me one industry that had a 27 per cent U.S. tariff against it, a tariff that was removed by the so-called free trade agreement? No.
Even if free trade was going to help Canadian companies expand into the United States, how could they when this government increased the value of the dollar by 27 per cent over that period?
We have seen how in our manufacturing sector Canada, since free trade, has lost 18 per cent of its manufacturing jobs, the highest paying jobs in our country. Looking at textile and garment workers, 27 per cent of those jobs have been lost from Canada.
Our auto sector is one of the best manufacturing sectors in this country, the largest investor, the largest exporter, employing over 100,000 Canadians. Since free trade we have lost over 28,000 auto jobs; 21 per cent of our auto workers are no longer employed. Do you think these jobs are going to come back after the recession is gone? All the figures show these plants have closed and moved out.
The best estimates are that at least two-thirds of the job losses during this so-called recession, this government created, government made recession, a recession that government brags about as being responsible management of our economy, are permanent.

May 8, 1992
Supply
We see the growing phenomenon of welfare cases. In my own city of Toronto the unemployment figures have just gone up from 10.6 per cent to 11 per cent. Those are the latest figures for Toronto which historically has been regarded as the engine for Ontario in Canada's growth.
There is increasing unemployment. At a time when the recession is supposed to be over, this government promised us more than a year ago that the recession was over, unemployment has increased in Toronto.
This is creating a desperate situation for those who are looking for work. Is there one member of Parliament in this House from any party who has not been faced with the situation where an unemployed person has come into his or her office and said: "Mr. Member of Parliament, I am 45 years of age. I have worked for 20 years. I have risen in the company; it has closed its doors. I have been looking for work now for a year. I have sent out 700 or 800 resumes. I read the paper everyday and I make phone calls. I am getting no responses. Nobody is hiring". A terrible tragedy it is.
Those people become takers, not because they want to, from the unemployment insurance fund and then from welfare. They are not contributing tax dollars to our coffers. The phenomenon one sees is people losing hope after having lost their jobs and having sought employment for so long but cannot find it. They lose their cars, they lose their homes. They lose their self-respect, their sense of worth and dignity, and many lose their families. This is the human tragedy which we see unrolling before us.
The unemployment insurance runs out now more quickly than it did before. They do not get 50 weeks of unemployment insurance; it is down to 40. When that runs out, they go on welfare, an odious term to all Canadians and particularly those who have to exist on it.
In Tbronto the welfare rolls are up 8.2 per cent in the first three months of this year. The welfare rolls are up 29 per cent over a year ago. We have a record 105,491 welfare cases in Toronto alone; 167,444 fellow Torontonians get by only because of welfare. Looking at the situation across Canada, two million Canadians are now depending on food banks and 700,000 of those are children.
We asked the government to come up with some programs to get people back to work so that they can become taxpayers rather than dependent on the programs. It said: "We cannot afford it". How much longer can we afford to support people on unemployment insurance and welfare?
It is a situation in our country that is worsening. It is a situation where this government, in its so-called stated strategies to make us strong in research and development, science and technology, training, is mouthing the right words but is cutting the funding.
This is a government that has cut contributions to the National Research Council, has obliterated completely the Science Council of Canada and has cut back on transfer payments to the provinces designed to fund education.
This is a government that says it has increased spending this year alone by $400 million to help training but it has actually cut the amount of money going into training. It has misled Canadians either because it is sinister and is deliberately trying to mislead Canadians or because it is ignorant and cannot read its own statistics.
This is a sorry day for Canada when looking at training. By forcing employers and employees to bear the full cost of its own economic mismanagement and incompetence this government has broken its social contract with Canadians. It is not accepting its share of the responsibility for these massive levels of unemployment and welfare.
When will this government stop misleading Canadians about what it is doing to get them out of the recession and to increase training? When will it change its economic agenda so that Canadians can get back to work?

Madam Speaker, the member's speech was very wide ranging. I cannot for a minute assume that I can cover all the detail that he did. However there are a couple of things I want to comment on. One of them is Canada's position in relation to the rest of the world.
The hon. member makes it sound as if Canada is the only country in the world that is suffering the recessionary blues. I think he has to explain that. Most of us in the House realize that Canada is only one nation in this world of ours and every nation, all the G-7 nations for
May 8, 1992

example, are going through the same difficulties we are in Canada.
The recession in Canada, although we do not want to downplay it, is bad. It is probably worse than we thought it was going to be but, goodness, I do not think he can get away with claiming the Government of Canada brought this recession on. We are just one nation in this world that is suffering from the same thing. If he is saying that the Government of Canada created the recession here, we have done the same thing in the rest of the world.
Did we create the recessionary blues in Japan, the United States or the western European countries? If we carry forward the logic he is presenting in the House this morning, the conclusion we reach is that Canada has such a tremendous impact in the world it brought the recession on in other comers of the world. That is not the case.
We are a very powerful nation. We have the seventh strongest economy in this world of ours, but based on the information the member presented in this House this morning I think there are some points which should be corrected by him.
The point I want to make this morning is that we are just one of many nations in the world that are suffering the recessionary blues. We are working to get out of it. I think there are some positive signs that we are moving forward and I think the member should recognize those.
He talks about dislocation in the work force. He is throwing figures back at us over here. Let us take examples in other countries of the world, because he is famous for getting on his hind legs and blaming free trade for all of the ills in the Canadian economy. He is talking about job dislocation in Canada. Let us talk about job dislocation in the industrial sector in the United States. The figure being used in the United States is a 4.5 million job loss in its industrial sector. On a comparative basis we are not doing any better or any worse than the United States.
If the hon. member is blaming job losses on us because of the free trade agreement, why is it that there has not been an increase in jobs in the United States? There has been a decrease in jobs in the United States. He should acknowledge that.

Madam Speaker, I have only two things to say to the hon. member. He has challenged me to explain first of all whether or not this recession was government caused.
His own finance minister admitted that he was pursuing recessionary policies and that they went too far. They put us into recession before any other country in the world. His own finance minister said that.
The hon. member says that Canada is not alone in facing difficult times. He is right. However, let us look at how much worse off we are than our major competitor, the United States, to which he referred. He said that the United States is having great difficulty. Yes, it is having difficulty. Since the free trade deal the United States has lost 10 per cent of its automotive jobs. Canada has lost 22 per cent. We are losing automotive jobs, a key manufacturing sector, at more than twice the rate the Americans are. We are falling behind more than twice as quickly as the Americans.
When we look at over-all unemployment figures, Canada is at 11 per cent, and that does not take into account the thousands upon thousands of Canadians who have dropped out of the workforce. Another 71,000 dropped out last month. They have given up looking for jobs so they are not even in those unemployment figures.
Over-all unemployment in the United States is not over 8 per cent yet. It is under 8 per cent. In Canada it is at 11 per cent, plus all these other people who have dropped out.
If he takes solace from those figures and says Canada is doing great, then he can go back and tell his unemployed workers. He should come to my riding and talk to unemployed workers because they just do not believe him or his government.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to start by saying how disappointed I am in the motion presented in this House by the hon. member for Willowdale, on the subject of job training and retraining initiatives for Canada's labour force.
According to this bizarre motion, the government failed miserably in its task to introduce measures that would give Canadians a chance to cope with the economic problems we are facing today like other industrialized countries. The hon. member for Willowdale blames the Department of Employment and Immigration which,
May 8, 1992

according to him, has failed to provide the House with adequate and factual information on this matter.
Anyone who has even the faintest idea of what is happening on the Hill and across the country must know that is not the case. If we look at what the present government has done since it came to power and at all the measures we have introduced for the benefit of Canada's workers we find that, on the contrary, the government has been very attentive to the needs of the Canadian labour force. The government has implemented a series of measures that we will discuss today, my colleagues and I, and that will demonstrate the government's commitment in no uncertain terms.
As for providing the House with accurate information,
I simply want to say that we are always very specific and factual in our announcements. We are also in the habit of letting the public know, through the various media, about measures and initiatives that are directed to Canada's workers. Throughout this country we are in touch with all Canadians who are temporarily out of work and must depend on unemployment insurance and welfare.
Consider, for instance, the Canadian Labour Force Development Board, the provincial and territorial boards, and some 60 local boards which are all part of a network that provides for effective communications between communities and the government.
As a government we have designed policies to meet certain challenges. The economic strategies we have been applying since 1984 promote sustainable growth and enhanced competitiveness. The globalization of our markets, the recession, inflation and political reforms all create pressures on national economies, forcing them to adjust and to do so with a great deal of flexibility.
Since our labour market problems are temporary and not cyclical, we need a long-term approach, while at the same time keeping day to day developments in perspective. That is what this government is doing. Our government has a good record for job creation.
Since the election in 1984, 1,170,000 jobs have been created. This month there will be 889,000 more women on the labour market than in 1984. We must focus our efforts on having an efficient and skilled labour force and on providing workers with ways to adjust to economic, professional and social change.
Supply
That is the pragmatic approach we have supported in recent years, starting with the passage of Bill C-21, when we decided to make a more dynamic and sensible use of unemployment insurance funds. This was a major breakthrough which has already had a positive impact, and we will continue to see the benefits of this decision in the years to come.
By using the Labour Force Development Strategy as a catalyst, we have concentrated our efforts on three essential aspects of the job world: an effective labour force, partnership and a consistent social policy.
As part of these intense consultations, representatives of business, labour, teachers and social action groups helped our department design and implement programs to upgrade the skills of the unemployed, make our workers better able to hold jobs that are continually changing and make Canadian labour more competitive on international markets.
As a result in only a few years spending on training the jobless has increased 62 per cent, which is a lot. We will come back to that.
I repeat that our goal is to increase the training provided by governments and the private sector. Through the prosperity initiative, we are trying to encourage a real learning culture in Canada. This must be done in partnership with all concerned.
In the new partnerships towards which we are moving, we must consider training and development as an investment rather than an expense. This applies to both the public and the private sector. Investing in human resources is as essential as investing in new technology.
Funds for training will increase by $300 million. This will be achieved by emphasizing active measures instead of passive support, and in co-operation with the provincial and territorial governments and the private sector. In that way, we will be better able to provide more effective training for Canadians.
The measures that our department is taking for the labour force tie in with the government's philosophy which seeks to replace passive support with active training and development initiatives. Above all, keep in mind that the purpose of the Labour Force Development Strategy is to produce highly skilled Canadian workers. It also lets the government follow through the recommendations of its private-sector partners by offering unemployed Canadians training and professional

Supply
development courses that are adapted to their various needs.
Adapting Canada's workers to the challenges of technology, the changes in the culture of work itself and the upheavals due to globalization is an endless ongoing process. It is like a huge wheel that keeps on turning and we are all part of it.
That is why our government, aware of its obligations, has gladly agreed to launch pilot projects in various parts of the country. By updating principles and techniques together in this way, we can open new avenues, find new opportunities, help advance knowledge and above all, Madam Speaker, make the country prosperous.
Madam Speaker, we agree on the need to harmonize our social programs-welfare, unemployment insurance, tax measures and labour market programs-in order to have consistent, productive policies and to encourage greater personal independence. I especially want to stress the financial independence of workers in my speech.
In this regard, we are pleased to launch today in Fredericton three initiatives that will provide incalculable benefits for all Canadians. The first is a pilot project that will be carefully monitored; we hope that the results will be conclusive. It is another step in the search for effective solutions to the problems of modem times. This is a research project of Employment and Immigration in cooperation with the New Brunswick Department of Income Assistance and the British Columbia Department of Social Services.
In this pilot project we will be able to test a way to help welfare recipients who are ready to work get off social assistance, obtain employment, and achieve a level of employment and work income that will make them independent. The basic purpose of the project is to provide a positive incentive to labour market participation, in order to make better use of the productive potential of welfare recipients.
We know very well that some of them have the necessary motivation and abilities to find work, but the starting salary is too low. This might be a valid reason for them not to work and to continue to collect welfare.
What we will do is provide a temporary income supplement which will make up the difference between the starting salary and the salary of an experienced worker.
The payment of this supplement would help overcome the deterring factors, facilitate job access and enable participants to free themselves more quickly from the welfare system.
In addition to the income supplement, participants would get financial and professional advice. They would also have access to other services in order to ensure their successful participation in the project.
The income assistance is dependent upon the number of hours worked by the participant, his or her salary, and the average salary in his or her community. The level of help is calculated so as to encourage the participant to do without welfare benefits. That level is rather high for low-income people in order to help them overcome the obstacles linked to their basic salary; that level then diminishes progressively as the salary increases.
The help provided will represent half of the difference between the actual earnings of the participant and a specific target. For example, in New Brunswick that target will originally be $25,000. Therefore, a participant earning $10,000 will receive $7,500, while a participant earning $20,000 will receive $2,500, for a total of $22,500.
We expect that by the end of the three years of eligibility, the earnings of many participants will have increased to a level where their salary will be better than welfare benefits. As I said earlier, this project is targeted to welfare recipients who have the motivation, the education and the required skills to work at a job, but who have been hesitant to do so, because the basic salary seemed inadequate to meet the needs of their families. Participation is strictly voluntary and we expect that 5,000 welfare recipients, many of them single mothers, will participate.
The project also includes a research component designed to individually assess the situation of participants, following their experience. Fifteen million dollars were allocated to New Brunswick, and 35 million dollars to British Columbia. The two provincial governments that contribute to the financing also participated in the development of this joint initiative. We must emphasize
May 8, 1992

the importance of these partnerships for the development of our country and for our prosperity.
The project is an important research experiment. We will be able to evaluate rather quickly the positive results of the project for the participants and see to what extent the benefits of that program vary from one to another. This will provide useful information on the various means that participants will have used to achieve selfsufficiency. This type of information will be essential in order to determine whether a program of that kind should be implemented on a permanent basis and how it should be designed and targeted.
The second project, New Brunswick at Work, is geared directly to welfare recipients who do not have a high level of education. The help provided by the government of New Brunswick, in co-operation with the federal government, will be tailored and geared to individual needs. Under that project $177 million will be used to improve the level of education of participants.
In its first year the project will enable 1,000 welfare recipients to participate in all kinds of programs dealing with literacy, occupational training and on-the-job training. This project will be financed by the Departments of Income Assistance and Advanced Education and Training of New Brunswick, jointly with Employment and Immigration Canada, as well as Health and Welfare Canada.
The savings in welfare benefits that would otherwise be paid to participants will be deposited in a fund which will be used to pay for training and for program related expenses.
Our third initiative is the renewal of the Canada-New Brunswick Agreement to improve employability of welfare recipients. Under this agreement each level of government will contribute up to $45 million, for a total of $90 million.
This initiative is based on a comprehensive approach aimed at helping people improve their employability, as well as facilitating access to federal and provincial programs and services.
These three projects mark the beginning of a new direction in social policies. Indeed we are more and more aware of the fact that social programs must promote
self-sufficiency and work. It is no longer appropriate to promote dependency and exclusion from the workplace for those who are capable of working and are willing to do so. For too many years, we have encouraged many Canadians to accept dependency at the expense of self-sufficiency. Therefore our priority must be to promote independence and personal freedom.

Madam Speaker, the United Nations has told us what many of us already knew, that Canada, no matter what our problems, is the very best place in the world to live. We cannot be complacent about that, especially those of us who were elected to help govern this great nation and to chart its course for the future.
We have a duty and an accepted responsibility to coming generations to leave them a country and a world that is in better condition than our generation found it.
Many of our future leaders are active now in Canada's 4-H clubs. I am delighted to have as guests here today a group of outstanding 4-H club members from Durham constituency. They represent Canada's future and they demonstrate that our nation will be in extremely capable hands.

Madam Speaker, the ice is packed solid along the Labrador coast and will be until the end of June. Yet unemployment insurance to fishermen will run out on May 15. The Government of Canada forces fishermen in Labrador to go for six weeks without income.

Declining fish stocks are doing an excellent job of cutting off the income of these people, yet the Government of Canada exploits a tragic situation by denying financial support to men and women who are trapped by nature and by the unemployment insurance system.
There will be no riots or demonstrations along the Labrador coast, but the hurt and the anger is there. It is real and it is justified.
Once more I call on the government to rectify this injustice and extend unemployment insurance on the Labrador coast until the end of June.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, throughout this National Forest Week the House has been reminded of the many benefits Canadians reap from our most valuable natural resource. The Minister of Forestry has been travelling the breadth of Canada from coast to coast joining in celebrations with thousands of Canadians as we pay tribute to our forest heritage.
This past week, special activities were organized and promoted across the nation in hundreds of small towns and cities. As Canadians, as stewards of a forest nation, it is our shared duty to recognize and understand the legacy, the importance and wise management of our forests.
I call on all Canadians to care for and use our priceless forests as the national treasure they truly are.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the outbreak of violence in Toronto revealed the existence of a serious unemployment problem among Canada's youth.
Today Statistics Canada reports that youth unemployment has reached 18.7 per cent in urban areas. This deplorable state of affairs creates a sense of hopelessness and aimlessness among our young people, our future leaders. Yet we know from past experience that young people are quite capable of being constructive contributors to Canadian society.
Do you remember, Madam Speaker, the Company of Young Canadians, Katimavik, Environment 2000, Youth Opportunities Program and the Local Initiatives Program? They demonstrated that young people can make a fine contribution if given the opportunity to do so.
Therefore, we urge the government to create youth employment programs and give our young people the opportunity to participate in the building of Canadian society.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Government of Canada has cut $217 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy funding. It is ordering the community training groups to take only UI recipients. This cuts out from training many sole support mothers, many immigrants, all people who have either had no chance to qualify for unemployment insurance or have used up their unemployment insurance entitlement.
Further, the government has ripped $1.8 billion from the premiums paid by workers and employers into unemployment insurance, cutting back their benefits so as to use them for training.
By contrast, the government of Ontario has announced funding for both jobs and job training. Job Training Fund, $1.1 billion over three years; Jobs Ontario Capital Fund, $2.3 billion over five years; Jobs Ontario Homes Fund, 20,000 new non-profit housing units. That will make a total of about 90,000 new jobs this year. It can be done even during a recession and I urge the federal government to get off its excuses and start funding jobs and training.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Prime Minister and the Minister of Agriculture have been fighting an uphill battle to maintain the integrity of our supply management system at the GATT talks. It appears now that our efforts may be paying off as news from Geneva indicates a deal could be in the works to save our marketing boards.
May 8, 1992

Under this new proposal the European Community has eased its position on converting border restrictions to tariffs calling instead for a deal that would include 90 per cent of what the European Economic Community first sought.
The Minister of Agriculture welcomes this change in attitude on the part of the EEC noting that: "If the European Community wants to leave out 10 per cent, as long as they are not export subsidies, I would trade them for leaving out supply management".
This is good news for supply management in this country and is further evidence of this government's continuing support for Canadian farmers.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, recently the Minister of Supply and Services was quoted as saying that he is thinking of imposing a service charge on government cheques. The minister explained this fee would recoup cheque printing and mailing costs and encourage automatic bank deposit.
I am astounded the minister is even contemplating such an aggressive idea. Employers in the private and voluntary sectors do not expect their employees to absorb the costs of printing cheques. It is unfair of the government to expect the recipients of federal cheques or federal employees to carry the burden.
How can the minister expect senior citizens on a fixed income, who received a negligible 37 cents per month increase this year, to pay for the luxury of receiving their cheques?
How can he levy a cheque fee on an unemployment insurance recipient? How does he expect people without bank accounts to take advantage of automatic depositing?
I call on the minister to abandon his plan and to look at other ways to save money.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise once again to speak to my constituents in the
Lethbridge federal electoral district concerning Senate reform.
The current Senate has virtually the same powers as this House of Commons yet does not often exercise these powers because by being appointed they lack political legitimacy. However once elected they will have political legitimacy and will exercise their powers fully.
Therefore I believe the Triple-E proposal is not in Alberta's best interest and, indeed, is plain dangerous. The reason is that a Triple-E Senate will transfer to 1 per cent of the population some 31 per cent of Senate seats.
Viewed another way, it will transfer to 9 per cent of the population who generate 10 per cent of the Gross Domestic Product an absolute majority of the Senate seats.
This is a radical shift of power which is not the best interests of Alberta and indeed not in the best interests of Canada as a whole.

speakerposition: subtopic
N.D.P. Caucus Chair
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, on the east coast the Department of Fisheries is trying to fix something that ain't broke. For generations lobster fishermen at Rustico and North Rustico, Prince Edward Island, have stored their traps on wharfs now owned by DFO. These wharfs are social centres where traps are repaired, where tourists take photographs and talk with the local people.
The Department of Fisheries and Oceans claims there is a fire risk. The local fire department says there is no risk. The people in these communities are unanimous in asking DFO to butt out.
On the west coast, Powell River and Tofino are losing their fishery patrol vessels, the Bonilla Rock and the Seal Rock. DFO tells us that one replacement vessel will be located at Tofino. One vessel could patrol either area but not two areas so far apart. Enforcement will be minimal. Illegal fishing will increase. Monitoring of streams and creeks will suffer. Supervision is important. Our west coast salmon fishery is a $1 billion dollar industry.
We must not let it go the way of the east coast cod fishery.

speakerposition: subtopic
Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is a privilege to draw the attention of the House today to the fact that Sunday, May 10, is Mother's Day. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the mothers who helped improve the quality of life of our country, who worked, taught, educated and cared for their children so they would grow up to be proud and prosperous Canadians.
I would like to extend my very special thanks to the mothers in the riding of Trois-Rivieres, especially those who will be alone this Sunday.
I also urge all children to visit their mothers and celebrate Mother's Day this Sunday.
Finally, Madam Speaker, I want to wish you a happy Mother's Day, and a happy Mother's Day, and many thanks to all mothers in the riding of Trois-Rivieres and across Canada.

speakerposition: subtopic
subtopic: ECONOMIC SITUATION IN GLENGARRY- PRESCOTT- RUS SELL

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: ECONOMIC SITUATION IN GLENGARRY- PRESCOTT- RUS SELL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in 1984, the Conservative government's campaign platform was based mainly on the following two themes: national reconciliation and economic renewal. Eight years later Canadians are still waiting for it to happen.
In my own riding, in Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, for instance, the promised economic renewal has yet to show its face. In Prescott County 1,511 were unemployed in 1990 which was far too many; 11,912 were unemployed in 1991; and today, 2,197, which is 14 per cent of the labour force in the county. The situation is not any better in Glengarry where 1,300 people are now on unemployment insurance.
I beg and beseech the government to set up economic renewal programs for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and for eastern Ontario as my colleagues and I have been asking for the past two years.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, an issue that is often raised by my constituents in Medicine Hat and I am sure in many other ridings relates to young offenders. The number of crimes being committed by young offenders is escalating and our judicial system appears to have increasing problems in addressing the situation.
As parents, most of us realize that part of growing up is testing the limits of the system. Educators in our schools face this on a daily basis. Those in authority must deal with young people on the streets of our towns and cities.
At one time there were standards or moral and ethical limits which while not drafted in law were boundaries which were seldom crossed. Our permissive society has changed and eroded many of those values: respect for authority, property of others and the rights of the individual, to name a few.
This problem crosses federal, provincial and municipal jurisdictions. Police at the local level often say that the paper work takes more time than the penalty. Provincial judges are reluctant to render a penalty to suit the crime because incarceration in the adult penal system would release young offenders and even-

speechtext: I am sorry, the hon. member's time has expired.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise today to inform the House that this year of 1992 marks the 400th anniversary of the discovery of the Strait of Juan de Fuca by the great Spanish explorer and seaman Juan de Fuca.
The Strait of Juan de Fuca is host to a large volume of local and international sea traffic and has proven invaluable to the citizens and businesses on Vancouver Island and on the British Columbia mainland.
The historical impact of Juan de Fuca's discoveries is evident in the fact that not only is my riding of Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca partly named after him, but also many organizations, businesses, hospitals and school districts on Vancouver Island.
May 8, 1992

I send my best wishes, and I hope the wishes of this whole House, to all those involved in festivities marking this important milestone. I was not present when he first arrived.

speakerposition: subtopic
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, on Monday of this week the Minister of National Health and Welfare announced Brighter Futures, a call to action for all Canadians on behalf of Canada's children.
One important component is a child development initiative which seeks to reduce conditions of risk in which many children, particularly young children, find themselves. This represents a $500 million commitment over the next five years.
I can tell all members of this House that the initiatives which focus on prevention, promotion and protection as well as partnership through community action have been well received in my riding of Sarnia-Lambton. "It is a terrific thing. Any opportunity to increase funding and services for children is more than welcome", said the executive director of the Sarnia-Lambton Centre for Children and Youth. "Any money that is invested in helping children is a positive move. I would think this will be applauded by the Children's Aid Society," said a board member of the local Children's Aid Society.
Thank you very much, Madam Speaker, for the opportunity to make this statement.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, according to recent studies more and more people are concerned about the economy and are afraid they will have to live in poverty.
For the first time since the depression people are afraid they will drop below the poverty level, be out of work and have no prospects of finding any work.
Oral Questions
This kind of fear which undermines the confidence of the individual and affects our human dignity is very destructive to society as a whole.
The situation demands drastic solutions, but unfortunately, our governments refuse to take a long hard look at what should be done.
I am in favour of governments, industry and social agencies meeting to exchange ideas and to find a way out of this crisis.

speakerposition: subtopic
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, today is World Red Cross Day which is commemorated by the International Red Cross and the Red Crescent movement in 149 countries around the world.
In Canada the Canadian Red Cross Society is marking the day with flag raising ceremonies, mayors' proclamations, and special events across the country.
This is the second year of the "Light of Darkness" campaign focusing on victims of war. Ninety per cent of today's victims of war are civilians. They are primarily women, children and the elderly.
The International Red Cross and the Red Crescent delegates work in troubled areas around the world like Cambodia, Somalia and Yugoslavia.
In the past year 38 Canadians worked abroad on many of these projects. I commend the work of these citizens, the Canadian Red Cross Society, the International Red Cross, and the Red Crescent movement on their efforts to "Light the Darkness" for victims of war and others in need around the world.

speakerposition: topic
subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
A year ago the government told us the recession was over. The deficit is up. Economic growth forecasts have been reduced. There are 180,000 fewer Canadians working today than were working a year ago, 220,000 people

Oral Questions
with no work in Toronto and 206,000 people with no work in Montreal.
How does the government justify failing to take any measures to help our ailing economy? How much longer can even this government tolerate the human misery it is causing?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member stands up and talks negatively time after time after time when there are many good signs showing up in the economy. We are coming out of a very difficult economic period which we all knew was coming and which we have come through.
The unemployment rate dropped, albeit a very small drop today. One of the good signs within that statistic is that there are 34,000 more manufacturing jobs and 24,000 more jobs relating to trade. That is a very important sign. Plus earlier in the week the business confidence level rose some 16 per cent. All these are good signs leading us out of a very difficult time.
If we all talked a little more positively about this great country we live in I think we would change attitudes and moods and help to encourage growth rather than discourage it like the hon. member tends to do all the time.

Madam Speaker, the truth is that this month 71,000 Canadians have given up looking for work altogether. Seventy-one thousand in one month.
Unemployment is increasing in Quebec City, in Montreal, in Sherbrooke, in Trois-Rivieres, and in Chicoutimi. Does he not realize his budget forecasts are out of whack? People who line up at soup kitchens do not pay taxes.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
First of all, Madam Speaker, budget control is not out of whack. The hon. member should be very careful in what she has to say because the final quarter figures are not in yet. I would ask her to be patient on that particular matter.
We as a government are continuing our work in encouraging employment. There was a major contract just recently awarded to Bell Helicopter in the province of Quebec which will have economic spinoffs in many provinces in this country but especially in the province of Quebec. There has been a major contract in Ontario just let which will not only preserve jobs but create jobs.
The federal government is doing its part. It behoves all of us to talk positively about the position Canada is in with the lowest inflation rate we have seen in three decades and the lowest interest rates in 20 years.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: As usual the hon. member for Willow-dale is delivering the best speech of his life from the seat of his pants. I might say that if we talked a little more positively about things it certainly would help the mood in this country.

Madam Speaker, the minister keeps repeating the same old song. His answers are unjustified and ancient.
The reality is that 71,000 Canadians this month simply gave up looking for work. That is why the numbers have changed. It is not because there are more people working; it is because people have simply given up all hope.
How can the minister continue to give these kinds of answers when he knows that Canadians are crying out for a real solution? Why does he not at least adopt the municipal works program that could put thousands of Canadians back to work today?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member wants the three levels of government to spend billions of dollars. We can get it from two areas. We can either raise taxes like Saskatchewan and Ontario did rather dramatically-and they have increased their public works expenditures in Ontario by just a few hundred thousand dollars-or we can also increase our deficit.
The Canadian people have told us loud and clear that they want the deficit down rather dramatically. That is what we are doing.
The hon. member said that I am not using current figures, that I am using some historical figures. Let me give her some current good news figures, if I might. New motor vehicle sales rose 2.6 per cent in April, following a 4.2 per cent increase in the first quarter. Those are today's facts. Housing starts rose 7.6 per cent in April.
May 8, 1992

Those are today's facts. Sales of existing homes increased 9.2 per cent. Those are today's facts.
The hon. member should start talking more positively about the economy.

Madam Speaker, I too have a question for the Minister of State for Finance. If he wants to have people talk positively then why does he not have a few words with his colleague, the Minister of Finance? Just yesterday the Minister of Finance admitted that the foundations of his budget, the projections in it for economic growth and the deficit were wrong. This will come as no surprise to anyone who is living through today's unemployment figures.
If the foundations of the budget, the projections on economic growth are wrong, does this not mean that the whole budget is wrong, the whole budget is off base? Why will the minister not admit this and get the government to bring in new measures now to get the economy growing strongly and get Canadians back to work?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is true that estimates have been somewhat modified from the budget, but I might point out that holds true for every other country in the world. The recovery throughout the world is not happening as fast as we would like, as everyone throughout the world would like. These figures have been lessened somewhat because of that particular thing.
As the hon. member knows, our largest customer takes 70 per cent of our exports, the United States. Its recovery has been slow. That is very important for Canada. It has slowed us down.
The important point is that even though those figures have come down, we are still in the best position of any country in the world to come out of the economic difficulties we have been through. That has been repeated by the OECD, by the IMF, by the World Bank, and by independent think-tanks outside government. They said we are in the best position.
Oral Questions
Even though the growth figures are reduced somewhat, we will still have the best growth in the OECD coming out of this. I think that is a very positive thing for us to be talking about.

Madam Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Minister of State for Finance.
He talks about important points. An important point is that in confirming the new forecast for lower growth his colleague, the Minister of Finance, said about the economy: "It could be weaker still".
Minister of State for Finance, meet the Minister of Finance. Now that the Minister of Finance has admitted that the economy "could be weaker still", what is the government doing about it? Is it not the government's job to have the economy and Canadians working? The million and a half people in this country without work demand and are entitled to a better answer than he is giving, a better answer right now.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in the 1981-82 period I sat in the House and watched the hon. member on the treasury benches throw money at problems. It did not solve anything in those days. We saw interest rates rise to 22 per cent. We saw unemployment at a rate of 14 per cent or 15 per cent. We saw inflation take off in this country because of those actions.
We are not doing that. We are not following in the manner the Liberals want us to follow because we learned the lessons of the early 1980s. That was not the way to solve the problems.
The way to solve the problems is to get the basics right. We have them in place now, and we are positioned to come out of the economic difficult times that we are in, in very good shape. That is what we are going to continue to do.
We are pleased that manufacturing employment has risen some 34,000 jobs. Trade related jobs are up some
24,000.	That is still not nearly enough, but it is moving in the right direction and we are encouraged by that.

May 8, 1992
Oral Questions

speakerposition: subtopic
N.D.P. House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, last night and early this morning Canadians were shocked to learn that the RCMP had paid an informant in the cabinet of an elected provincial government in an effort to collect political information.
My question is for the Minister of Justice. Is the minister aware of the policy of the previous government by which the RCMP used informants to gather political information about a legitimately elected government in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the events to which the hon. member refers and which have been the subject of news reports in the last 24 hours refer to events that took place over 20 years ago.
All the activities of the security service of the RCMP were very closely examined by the McDonald commission of inquiry. The government of the day decided as a result of that inquiry to establish a separate security intelligence service under ministerial control with independent external review.
I believe the knowledge of the government of the time was very much a reflection of the McDonald commission and that the government of the time took the appropriate steps in ensuring that such incidents would not happen again.
I can say that the CSIS Act, because it was CSIS that was established to be the security intelligence service, specifically prohibits the service from investigating activities solely constituting lawful advocacy, protest and dissent.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the minister says that this happened 20 years ago. Of course it happened 20 years ago and as recently as 1981.
I think Canadians are appalled at this revelation last night and this morning. Therefore, in order to remove this pall that now hangs over the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and perhaps even the government, will the minister assure this House and the people of Canada that her government has no policy and certainly no practice that would see the RCMP using paid political informants to gather political information regarding a
legitimate, elected provincial government or any other elected government?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would repeat again that as a result of the inquiry into the actions that the hon. member refers to, the Government of Canada created an independent security intelligence service. That security intelligence service is strictly governed by an act which prohibits the kind of investigation he is talking about.
Moreover, there is an independent review mechanism which consists of Privy Councillors of all political stripes of this country and which from time to time also communicates with parliamentary committees.
I believe there is both a policy in place and a mechanism in place to assure Canadians of the proper use of our security intelligence service in the protection of lawful activities of political advocacy or dissent.

Madam Speaker, I wish to thank the Minister of Justice for her answer, but I would like to expand on the situation we learned about last night just a bit further.
In the past there have been provincial governments that have not been of the mainstream parties. In the case of my own party, the CCF was involved in many progressive, daring new legislative initiatives. In my own case in British Columbia, we too were involved in such initiatives between 1972 and 1975.
I would like to ask the minister to inform this House whether or not to her knowledge, or if she could find out, governments of the day are continuing to do the same thing when legislation is introduced by a provincial government, that they are using informants to gather political information for political purposes.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I cannot add anything to what I have already said. This was a question that deeply concerned Canadians when the McDonald commission took place and presented its results. The government of the day responded by creating an independent security intelligence service under ministerial control and with an independent review.
May 8, 1992

The independent review mechanism is there. If the hon. member has any specific concerns there are mechanisms and devices to address those concerns. The process is in place. The policy is in place, secured by legislation and a process of review.
I think there is really nothing more to add to that process.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the acting minister of employment. The youth unemployment rate stands at 16.8 per cent which means that over 400,000 young Canadians are standing in the unemployment lines of this nation. Many of them feel neglected and alienated by this government.
When will it become a vehicle of opportunity for young Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, if we compare the youth unemployment rate with what it was when we came to power in 1984, we can say that unemployment among our young people has gone down. We can also tell our young people that the best way for them to have a decent future is to correct the state of our finance. We are working on it, and we will succeed.
We also have a message for Canada's youth: keep acquiring the knowledge and skills you need to do the kind of jobs for which training is necessary in a new world market. I especially want to say: "Never give up looking for work because we can help through our Department of Employment and Immigration, with our work adjustment and job entry programs".

Madam Speaker, the minister's answers are old and tired just like her government.
Young people in Canada are disillusioned and disappointed by a system that does not provide them with job opportunities. Young people in this country want a new contract.
Oral Questions
When will this government stop wasting our most important human resource? When will it do something to get our young people off the streets and into jobs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Madam Speaker, we have summer employment programs for young people to help them acquire job experience during their school holidays. These programs work very well. The budgets have been increased for this year. It is an opportunity for young people to acquire skills and over the years make a career for themselves in organizations that are working in partnership with the federal government.

speakerposition: subtopic
Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Madam Speaker, the recession continues in Montreal, where the unemployment rate is now up to 12.9 per cent. This means that in April, 3,000 more people in Montreal were out of work. In the Montreal area, 100 jobs per day were lost during the month of April which means four more unemployed every hour of every day, for 30 days. Why has the government refused to take part in a municipal infrastructure strategy to create jobs as suggested by the Leader of the Opposition and the mayor of Montreal?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, perhaps I may remind the hon. member that the government has done a great deal in the Montreal area. Not long ago I heard the Quebec industry minister explain his cluster theory. He gave several examples of a constructive approach to development, especially the Montreal region. I was not surprised to hear that the only examples of sectors that worked were those initiated by the federal government. I am thinking of the aviation industry, pharmacies and so forth.
The government is doing a lot, although the fact remains that Montreal still faces some very serious problems which are of great concern to us. We are discussing this on an ongoing basis with the Government of Quebec.

May 8, 1992
Oral Questions

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Madam Speaker, the minister just said the government is doing a lot. If that is the case, why did 8,000 people in Montreal give up hope in April alone? Why is Montreal's unemployment rate up to almost 13 per cent? If you are doing a lot, why does the unemployment rate not go down?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext: Madam Speaker, we are doing a lot, but the government does not create jobs. This technique has been tried in Eastern Europe, for instance, where the government had shoe factories and automobile plants, and it was a total disaster. The government can help businesses, which create the jobs, by bringing interest rates down, and that is what we are doing. It means creating conditions that will make us competitive, and that is what we are doing.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Employment and Immigration.
Labour force information for April 1992 shows the continuing exodus of workers from the labour market who have simply given up looking for work in response to dismal job prospects.
The participation rate has declined for the sixth straight month. The continuing decline of employment means that 188,000 jobs have been lost since October 1991.
What is the minister prepared to do immediately to put people in this country back to work?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
First of all, Madam Speaker, with the Labour Force Development Strategy we can give workers who are looking for employment a range of programs suited to their needs.
I again ask workers who are looking for employment not to lose hope and give up their search. With this strategy we were able to spend $3 billion on training and
adjustment last Ayear. There is a social consensus from all quarters that we should have a more active program and work in partnership. I could give many examples from Quebec, since I am much more in Quebec as a result of my responsibility, showing that by working together as partners, we can have hope and maintain this culture of hope. I repeat what my colleague just said about having a positive approach. Let us be a little more positive and try to create hope and together we can succeed.

Madam Speaker, Canadians have not given up hope; they want jobs. They are still looking for work, but there is none. I therefore want to ask a supplementary question.

People become part of the unemployment statistics by qualifying for unemployment insurance. Is it not true that there are thousands of people who want to work but are no longer part of the statistics because they are now on welfare?
This government is distorting the figures by using only those statistics that indicate those people who are on unemployment insurance. It is trying to cloud the issue to make itself look better in the eyes of Canadians by not using the real figures which are closer to 20 per cent unemployment.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Madam Speaker, what we are being told here is quite wrong. Keep in mind that we are just getting out of a world-wide recession. Major restructuring is under way, which of course means that some jobs are lost and new ones are created. That is what we are working on as a government. We do not forget the unemployed. We are setting up programs to be able to provide adequate training. We are convinced that we will succeed and of course we ask workers to apply for these programs. We call on those with projects to create employment. We are there to provide training and we are trying to do that.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the President of the Treasury Board who just answered a question from my
May 8, 1992

colleague from Saint-Leonard about the economic slump in the greater Montreal area.
Why does the government not agree to be a partner? I hear the minister from the Rimouski region who just said that her government is seeking partnership. One way to bring back employment quickly is major public works. We know that in the municipalities, as the mayor of Montreal said clearly himself, it would be possible to create thousands of jobs very quickly in the next few weeks if a whole municipal infrastructure program was launched.
Why does his government, which loves talking about partnership, not act with the municipal and provincial authorities to rebuild municipal infrastructure, not only in Montreal but throughout the country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, one of the main reasons is that this government, as a result of very bad Liberal management, inherited a debt which leaves it very little room to move. That is a fact. From the beginning the Conservative government has been busy putting the government's finances back in order. We are solving the problem; after 1994-95 we will no longer have to borrow.
But we still have a deficit in fields of exclusive federal jurisdiction. Instead of spending their money on extremely luxurious facilities, some municipalities have invested in infrastructure like water supply systems and so on. Other municipalities have made different choices.
Therefore I think it would be very inappropriate to put everyone on the same footing and say that we would help municipalities that have spent wisely and not put their money in stadiums or that sort of thing.
We think it is a municipal responsibility and municipalities have spent very little on it. If it is really a priority for them, the figures should show that over the years.
In any case, the government is always prepared to look at what it might do with the provincial authorities based on what it can afford. There is no question of borrowing
Oral Questions
billions, which we do not have, to add to the debt and next year lose the ability to help Canadians in need.

Madam Speaker, it is really pathetic to hear a government minister go back eight years to justify his incompetence and inaction in creating jobs today in 1992.
If the minister says there was a large deficit in 1983-84, fine, but will he at least have the decency to admit that he is responsible for the government's annual deficit of $31 billion in 1991-92? He cannot blame it on those who were in power ten years ago.
If we have economic problems today, they are due to the Conservatives' incompetence and nothing else. I ask the minister if, given the terribly high unemployment, throughout Canada today and especially in Montreal, he will have the heart to restore the home-building programs that are so necessary for job creation. It is well known that the construction industry drives the economy and when construction is booming, so is the economy.
I ask the minister to restore the home building programs as soon as possible; they will provide the community, co-operative and social housing that the people need.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Yes, I see. Yesterday, it was roads, then infrastructure, and now housing.
Where will the government get the money? By raising taxes. Unfortunately Canadians think that they are already taxed enough.
The hon. member also says that we have been in power for seven years, which is true, and that we should have solved the problem. But the problem which the Liberals left us is so big that it is very difficult. We have turned the situation around. We were unable to pay even the employees' salaries; we had to borrow $16 billion. We started with minus 16, we cut and went up to minus 12, minus 8, zero. This year, thanks to the government's competence, we have a $12 billion operating surplus. However, the debt eats up these surpluses and forces us to continue to run a deficit.
Only good management will get us out of this fix.

Madam Speaker, last February 21, as a result of the northern cod reduction the processing plant in Catalina-Port Union in my riding was closed. Seventy communities were affected, 1,100 people lost their jobs overnight and those 80 families had no form of compensation because they were not covered by unemployment insurance.
The same day I asked the minister what form of compensation could be expected and I got a general, non-committal answer. I have asked a couple of questions since and I still have no specifics.
I ask the minister this. The government has had two and a half months to think about this. Can I expect some form of compensation? When will this be announced and what form will it take?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as Minister of State for Employment, I am always concerned when I hear of situations like these. We could of course look for a way out in conjunction with the private sector. A variety of programs exist within the department, as we have said time and again, to help workers find a new placement and to help companies forced to proceed to massive layoffs carry out studies and assess what the future holds for them. That is what we are working toward.
I will take note of the question which is very specific and falls within the jurisdiction of my colleague and will get back to the member on this as soon as possible.

Madam Speaker, I am somewhat disappointed in the minister's answer. She is normally very compassionate and caring. This has not been a very good answer to the question. My heart really goes out to those people who have to watch and listen to these kinds of answers.
In March the minister of fisheries announced a task force on adjustment programs for those people involved in the fisheries and in the loss of their jobs. He also announced that there would be a $45 million fund available for pilot studies.
These people to whom I refer, and a lot of them are watching this today, do not need a pilot study or a pilot project to tell them when to get up in the morning. They have no jobs to go to. They have very little opportunity to find work. There is none whatsoever. They have no food on the table and now they are beginning to lose hope.
I ask this minister one more time to put a face on the situation and try to show some compassion for those people who, through no fault of their own, are in trouble and are crying out for help.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Madam Speaker, when you think of the $55 million assistance and all the other programs we have provided. We have come up with special initiatives geared toward fishing and other affected areas. We must of course work for the present. Look at as many pilot projects as you will, the fact remains that it is important to sit down with the employer and the worker and figure out precisely what their needs are for the future. It takes creativity and pilot projects, and that is what studies are for. Let us try and find new ways to meet future needs. For the time being, however, what we are trying to do within the limits we have in this government is to focus on the training and adjustment of the workers, men and women.

He will recall that a meeting was convened in Toronto last fall to consult members of the ethnocultural and minority groups which among some, including the chairman, was considered unsatisfactory because it was not an opportunity for a real exchange.
I understand that there is a meeting to be held this afternoon. I would ask the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs whether this is an indication that the government is prepared to discuss with minority
