groups the question of a revision to section 27 that would respond to the plea for a concrete recognition of equality in the Constitution?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, throughout this constitutional process with the active help of members on all sides of the House of Commons, I have been trying to consult as broad a group of Canadians as I can. One of the ways that has been done is by trying to arrange meetings with particular groups which we knew had particular concerns.
I would like to express publicly my appreciation to the Canadian Ethnocultural Council for its help in putting this afternoon's meeting together. The purpose of the meeting is for me to give an update on some of the discussions that are occurring in the multilateral constitutional negotiations.
Naturally, if there is a view put forward, I will be there to listen to it. If there is a consensus around that view it will naturally have more weight. But I cannot make any guarantees either in the House now or in that meeting later this afternoon as to what the multilateral process might decide.

I presume that the government will look at the position now taken by the Government of Ontario that section 27 should be supported in the constitutional process.
I put it to the minister that I am sure he understands. Given the sensitivity of the present environment, it is important in these kinds of discussions that the people participating, particularly from the black community, be as representative as possible, and that they be not coloured by apparently partisan choices.
Before I go on I want to thank the minister for having added one person to that group who was very representative of the community in Toronto. Does the minister not think that it is going to be seen as peculiar that up until now the two Afro-Canadian representatives were both from Nova Scotia, both Conservatives, one a member of the Constitution committee, a senator? Yet no other visible minority members in this place who could have contributed by virtue of their credibility in their own communities were included in the invitation to this meeting.

Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the minister replying for the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
On Monday the minister announced the components of the Brighter Futures campaign, the federal government's action plan for children in Canada. One component, the child development initiative, represents a $500 million commitment to help reduce conditions of risk for our children.

Madam Speaker, this comment comes as a breath of fresh air in this House. Finally, people are positive and approve of what we are doing. It makes my day.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Acting Minister for the Environment.
This week Canada has been negotiating the draft climate change convention. We have just been told that this convention will not be internationally binding and will contain no specific goals and timetables for stabilizing greenhouse gas emissions.
Why did the Canadian government give in to American pressure and approve a meaningless agreement that has no teeth?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, discussions with respect to the negotiations in question are continuing. It may well be that both the question and my answer may prove to be eclipsed by subsequent events.
What I can say is that Canada entered into these negotiations with some very specific objectives in mind. We were committed to the establishment of greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000. We were anxious to ensure that as many nations of the world as possible be committed to that process. The problem of climatic change is a global one and therefore the solution must also be global in nature.
Furthermore, we were determined that some necessary financial assistance and technology transfer would be available to developing countries.
At this time we have every reason to be encouraged by the results. There is every indication that a very substantial number of countries are going to make a commitment going into and at Rio. We are very pleased by the fact that the Prime Minister of Canada will be a part of that process. We are particularly pleased that there will be a global response to what is a global problem.

May 8, 1992

Madam Speaker, failure at the UNCED conference in Brazil will have terrible long-term consequences for the ecosystem of the world. However, there is one thing worse and that is failure camouflaged by grand sounding, empty agreements designed not to pull the world back from the brink of environmental disaster but to hide the fact that we are about to plunge over the precipice. That is what any agreement without firm timetables and targets will do. That describes the agreement that was announced in climate change in New York.
The parliamentary secretary says that the agreement has not been signed. Will the parliamentary secretary give us an undertaking today that this government will not go along with the farce, that it will not sign an agreement that gives the green light to business as usual? Will the government give us a firm undertaking that it will not sign an agreement without firm timetables, without firm targets, without teeth?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member is being unduly pessimistic. He will recall there was an agreement, the 1985 Vienna Convention, which started international co-operation dealing with stratospheric ozone depletion.
That particular agreement might not have won the support of the hon. member at that particular time had he been a member of the House. In fact it has lead today to some very specific timetables and some very specific targets with respect to the control and elimination of CFCs.
We in the international community as a result of a process that began back in the early 1980s are on the eve of a very important resolution on the production and use of CFCs which has been a real threat to the ozone layer.
I predict that with the co-operation of the international community we will come out of Rio with a similar kind of promising agreement.
Oral Questions EXTERNAL AFFAIRS

Madam Speaker, two Canadians, David Spencer and Christine Lamont, are in Brazilian prisons. We have seen the pictures of torture with those people involved.
Amnesty International says torture is endemic in Brazil. It can happen any time, anywhere, in police stations, in police vehicles, in prison, and in secret.
In light of the fact that the Secretary of State for External Affairs saw her way clear to leap to the assistance of a convicted murderer on death row in Texas but refuses to help Christine and David, would the minister please explain the double standard?
That is shameful.
It is true.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member is not accurate in his statements. In fact, the consular services of the Canadian government in Brazil were offered. I understand the legal remedies in Brazil have not been proceeded with to their limit.
As the Secretary of State for External Affairs has said, we have in process and indeed signed at our end a prisoner exchange program and there is simply not the evidence to point out that the trial was anything but fair. By our standards the sentence seems long.
In terms of the individual in Texas we would, wherever a Canadian was sentenced to death, ask for clemency on behalf of that. We are not asking that the individual in Texas be released. We are not claiming he is innocent. We are asking that he not be put to death in keeping with the standards we maintain in this country.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36,1 am pleased to present a petition duly certified by the clerk of petitions from 30 citizens of the Buckhom and surrounding areas in my riding of Victoria-Haliburton who are concerned about the constitutional process.
These petitioners request the enactment of legislation which would provide for a referendum of the people with respect to constitutional amendments.

May 8, 1992
Routine Proceedings

Madam Speaker, among the petitions I wish to table today, there is one from the Club de l'age d'or de Marie-Mediatrice, in my riding of Vanier.
The petitioners are calling on Parliament to press the government to reinstate the Court Challenges Program. As we all know this program must continue to serve as an indispensable tool for the development of constitutional rights and to give equal access for all Canadians to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. This program costs less than 10 cents per year and benefits all Canadians.
The petitioners humbly pray that Parliament reconsider the decision to do away with the Court Challenges Program which was giving all Canadians equal access to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

Madam Speaker, I rise to present two petitions today. The first states that many women in Canada are living in poverty after years of homemaking which allowed their husbands to pursue careers without the burden of childbearing and housework.
Many of these women are disentitled by divorce to an equal share of their husbands' federal pension credits accumulated during their marriage.
The petitioners from all over British Columbia call on this Parliament to consider amending all federal superannuation acts in which inequities exist to allow for the retroactive pension credit splitting for all divorced spouses so that they receive one-half of the federal pension credits accumulated by both spouses during their years of marriage.

Madam Speaker, my second petition is from citizens in the city of New Westminster British Columbia who state that the post office on Columbia Street in our city provides an excellent and necessary service to all of the residents of New Westminster.
The closing of this post office and its replacement by a commercial service centre for services to business only established two classes of Canadians. This decision which affects the residents of New Westminster was made without any consultation.
These petitioners call on Parliament to halt the plans to close the New Westminster post office on Columbia Street. They do not want it replaced with a commercial service centre.

Madam Speaker, I have a duty to present a petition with regard to the national campaign to support reinstatement of the Court Challenges Program.
As hon. members are aware, this program has been used for the past 15 years. Through this program people had a right to defend their constitutional rights before the courts or at least to have these rights clarified and to obtain recognition through the courts of the language and equality rights in our Constitution.
In the name of these people from Hamilton and the Niagara area, I would respectfully pose this to the House.

The abolition of the Court Challenges Program is a great loss for social justice and equality in our country.

Madam Speaker, I rise to present a petition signed by many residents in Ontario concerning the Court Challenges Program which has allowed many individuals and minority groups to clarify through the court their constitutional, linguistic and equality rights.
The Court Challenges Program continues to be essential in the development of legal procedures involving the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The abolition of the Court Challenges Program is an incalculable loss to equality and social justice in this country.
These petitioners urge the government to consider the advisability of reinstating the Court Challenges Program which helps make the Charter of Rights and Freedoms accessible to all Canadians.
May 8, 1992

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise in accordance with Standing Order 36 to present a petition from my constituents of Carleton-Charlotte. It has been certified correct as to form and content by the clerk of petitions.
The constituents call upon Parliament to enact legislation providing for: (a) a referendum of the people binding upon Parliament to accept or reject constitutional amendments proposed by the government, and, (b) the acceptance or rejection of the proposed amendments to be determined by a majority vote of the total votes cast in the whole of Canada together with a majority vote in a majority of provinces with the territories being given the status of one province.

Madam Speaker, it is my honour to rise today with a petition on behalf of victims and families of those suffering from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis or ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. These people are petitioning the government to invest in research to find a solution to this veiy serious illness.
I would add that in addition to the many names on the petition that I have in my hand a very large number, perhaps over 10,000 petitions, were passed directly to the office of the Prime Minister of Canada expressing the concern of many people in Canada about this disease and the need for research into a solution.

This has become a particular problem in urban areas. In my own constituency of Ottawa South the waiting period for determination of refugee status is very long. It results in decisions that are seen by many as being rather inhumane when residents of long standing are found not to have refugee status and are sent away from the country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I was simply saying before Question Period that the curriculum change we have announced totally disproves the motion before this House today. So, I am understandably disappointed such a motion was put forward.
The way we work is through the political will to serve the work force by suggesting effective and practical solutions to their problems. This change is designed to make Canadian social policies much more responsive to the true needs and aspirations of people who want work, not a handout and tons of compassion.
By enhancing the skills and income earning potential of our most precious resource, namely the worker, we as a government make sure that all Canadians have the opportunity to help our shared dream of a united, prosperous and internationally competitive country come true.
I just wanted, following Question Period, to illustrate this partnership and the common purpose between employer and employees by way of a few examples I am familiar with such as the petrochemical industry in Quebec. A request for project funding was submitted in order to set up a committee to establish such an industry there. Jobs in that area have been in short supply for years. High qualification standards, the growing manpower demand and especially the lack of skilled labour in the labour market were the main reasons it was so hard to hire people.

Agreed.

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
So, members of this industry, unions, along with other partners, formed a manpower adjustment committee, better known as a MAC within my department. Major training requirements were identified and it was suggested to set up, in conjunction with a college in the east of Montreal, a training centre in petrochemistry, chemistry and related fields.
Believe it or not, 40 people are working together around the same table. We work with the private sector, with the unions, the workers, the employers and with Quebec's own institutions. Responsibilities are shared and subsidies are provided by the Quebec Department of Education, the Manpower Department and the Department of Employment and Immigration, plus industry's contribution. This illustrates our government's ability to get things done and find effective ways to co-operate.
Another aluminum plant is now under construction and is expected to open this spring creating 450 to 500 jobs. Mechanics and electricians will be needed which means skills training. A training agreement has been signed by both departments and the college with the private sector, and 45 mechanics and 25 other workers will be trained, thanks to a financial contribution of $1.2 million from our department.
A cement plant employs 150 workers, but there is a shortage of manpower with skills in new technology so that skills training is needed. That is another example to illustrates our ability to respond to these needs through our training programs.
A school board needs training for workers in the pulp and paper industry. We are right there with the provincial government. A manpower adjustment committee for the aerospace industry has been set up and a parity committee for the plate glass industry. I could give many more examples, of this type of partnership in Quebec and elsewhere in Canada. Of course I am more familiar with what is being done in Quebec because I am responsible for that particular sector, while my colleague works for the other provinces. However, I know for a fact that across Canada, employers and workers, and federal, provincial and municipal governments, want to work together to find the right solutions.
Because our government is aware of these problems it has taken a number of initiatives to encourage young people to stay in school, to help Canadians who need training and to prepare the Canadian labour force for the challenges of the twenty-first century.
We talk increasingly about upgrading knowledge and a continuum of training. Personally, I talk about a culture of hope. Indeed the Economic Council of Canada has just published a very interesting summary of this question. The report is entitled A Lot to Learn.
Our department and our government work with that in mind. Let us cultivate hope and knowledge. Far from being indifferent to the training and development of Canadian workers, our government keeps abreast of what is going on in the world of work. It establishes partnerships that advance the cause of workers. It maintains relations with all concerned and all interested groups. It provides programs that are both effective and up to date. It even conducts studies in order to find the solutions of the future. That is what it is doing, what it has done in the past and what it will continue to do. As Minister of State for Employment, I have faith in the ability of workers, employers and governments to work together for a better quality of life and to create jobs for the future in a world of globalizing markets.

Madam Speaker, the motion before us which was moved by the member for Willowdale, asks that this House pass a motion condemning the government and the Minister of Employment and Immigration for quote: "his continual failures to provide the House and the people with accurate and unambiguous factual information on this matter".
We learned this morning about a decline of some 14,000 unemployment insurance recipients or claimants. Those people have given up looking for jobs; they have decided that the system does not work for them. The unemployment rate dropped from 11.1 per cent to 11 per cent.
We should not take heart but rather worry because the minister, in her comments, said that the government was delighted that Bill C-21, which privatized the unemployment insurance program, was passed. We know now that unemployment insurance is an insurance program that is financed 60 per cent by the employer and at 40 per cent
May 8, 1992

Government Orders
by the employees. The government no longer contributes to that program.
There is a program about which the government can rightly say that it is involved: the job creation strategy. However, Madam Speaker, if you look at the Estimates for this year and last year you will note that federal contributions have fallen by $114 million. The federal government reduces its contribution to manpower training. It no longer participates in the unemployment insurance program and now the minister is asking us to trust employers and employees. I understand. The burden is on their shoulders. What will the government do to help Canadians find a job that will ensure their future in this country? The government must act soon because 1.5 million Canadians are out of work.
I ask the minister: What will the government do to give hope to those people instead of present information that is not always totally accurate and is sometimes very ambiguous?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, 300,000 jobs have not been filled because workers did not have the required skills.
We work on training, developing skills and acquiring experience to ensure that workers regardless of age can apply for the jobs that are offered. If our workers had the necessary skills to fill those 300 000 jobs, the unemployment rate would be even lower.
I simply want to remind the House that we, the federal government, continue to manage the unemployment insurance program. We have not delegated all the responsibilities related to the program. Let us not suggest to this House and to Canadians that we as a government have withdrawn from the program, that we have thrown in the towel. We co-operate with employers and with employees, and this manpower strategy that we have implemented enables us to precisely redirect the training of workers to provide them with the required upgrading and, as many companies recommended to us, to implement an active program to replace a passive one that did not provide for training.

Madam Speaker, the once flourishing shipbuilding industry in British Columbia has come to a standstill, largely because of the broken promises of the federal government, along with its so-called rationalization policy. The minister will recall the Polar 8 ice-breaker, twice promised by senior ministers, was cancelled. There has not been a fair allocation of other federal shipbuilding contracts to compensate the west coast and keep our industry going.
The Versatile Pacific shipyards were closed about two years ago and over 300 senior workers, highly skilled shipbuilders, were laid off, with no severance pay and no hope of retraining. These older workers have had to live on their savings and many of them today are on welfare. Yet the federal government which promised to assist with worker adjustment programs has done nothing. Recently the west coast Manley shipyard construction division closed with other additional workers laid off. Our shipyard industry, which once was thriving, is dying.
I would like to ask the minister why the government will not take the initiative because I know she cares about older workers. Will she not take some initiative on behalf of these workers who have given over 25 years of their lives to Canada in many cases as skilled shipbuilders. Will she look into this matter and will she ask the government to undertake initiatives on behalf of these workers so that they will have some form of adjustment compensation?
Will she also inform the Vancouver members of Parliament what action has been taken so that we in turn can inform our constituents?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as I said earlier, when we hear about a major restructuring of the global economy, we unfortunately hear about job losses at the same time. We must also talk about new jobs being created. We are aware that the industry you are talking about has been going through tough times at the financial, economic and social level.
The issue of older workers is one of particular concern to me. I have pointed out several times already that we would be interested in satisfying this need for recognition of the older worker through our adjustment pro-

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
grams. It seems to me that we will have to come up with appropriate action.
The time has come to change our social policies. The capacity of the older worker to produce and to allow us to benefit from his or her experience regardless of his or her age must be recognized. As part of our job strategy we have adjustment programs. We have all kinds of schemes, strings of programs to find the appropriate solutions. Each request the department receives is considered extremely important. I can understand the hon. member's concern for the issue he is committed to. We must work together in co-operation with the Minister of Employment and Immigration to find the appropriate solutions. Just knowing that we can work together in co-operation gives hope of finding these solutions.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question to the minister is about the free trade deal with the United States. During the election campaign the government promised training programs so that all displaced workers would be able to enter other industries or sectors. The minister and I are both from the province of Quebec. She will recall, as I do, the massive support given to the free trade deal by Quebecers during the election, because they were told, by both the federal and provincial governments, that there would be training programs to provide for this adjustment. They were guaranteed that there would be programs.
Three and a half years later we are still waiting for that program. I recall very well that after the election when we got back to the House questions were asked about that. The government replied that the programs that were in place were sufficient and were meeting the needs. How can they still say that those programs are meeting the needs when we learned this morning that unemployment is close to 13 per cent in the Montreal region alone and 12.5 per cent for the whole of Quebec. According to the official UI figures there are almost half a million unemployed Quebecers, not counting those who are on welfare or gave up looking for a job. Can the minister tell us when we will have that program? Will it be part of another election promise, or will we have it now?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, when I took part in the election campaign in 1988 and we talked about free trade, I equated free trade with an invitation to learn and to compete. When we want to compete globally and internationally, we must have the necessary talents and skills.
That is why our government had a policy aiming at increasing training opportunities. And I remember very well the long fight we had in this House to get Bill C-21 passed.
The opposition objected to the passing of Bill C-21 which changed our system to an active one. We lost one year. The government is aware of the continuing need for labour force training and adjustment in order to facilitate the reintegration of the unemployed into the labour force and to meet the global challenge.
I just want to remind you that training activities will be increased by $300 million in 1992-1993, which will bring the total expenditures to $3.4 billion. This is what we are working on, starting with the examples I mentioned among which are those I know well in Quebec and others at the national level. We are trying to make sure that our labour force is competitive at the provincial, national and international level.

Madam Speaker, it is not with a great deal of pleasure that I rise today to speak on this motion. It is not a pleasure to speak about the problems we face in this country, the problems unemployed workers are facing on a daily basis. However I welcome the opportunity to make a few comments.
Let me begin by saying that in my opinion we do not have a minister of employment, we have a minister of unemployment. This minister talks more about unemployment, about people out of work, than he does about putting people back to work.
He relies on making statements about people being underqualified. We had a work force in this country that was surviving quite well prior to the recession, prior to the failure of the economic policies of this government. These were skilled people. They were functioning on a daily basis, sustaining themselves, supporting their families, paying their taxes and surviving quite well. Now they are out of work. They are out of work as a result of the
May 8, 1992

recession caused in part by this government and its policies.
Now they are being told that they do not have the skills to find a job. I challenge any member of this government to come to my riding of Timmins-Chapleau, stand in front of the hundreds of qualified miners, hundreds of qualified foresters and tell them they are not qualified to work in their trade. They are qualified to the extent that they are able to teach other people how to work in those trades.
Why are they not working? Why is there not more emphasis on getting them back to work? What are we going to train these people to do? We cannot make brain surgeons out of everyone in the country. There is a job market for the skills we have in this country. We do have a skilled labour force.
The minister earlier spoke about some 300,000 jobs that are available but we do not have the ability to fill those jobs because our workforce is not trained properly.
When a person goes to the unemployment office as result of a job loss and applies for unemployment he would apply for training under section 26 of the act.
If that person has certain skills above the ability to earn minimum wage, in other words, if a person is an accountant and is out of work and asks for assistance under section 26, he does not qualify for retraining because he is already qualified. Therefore that person cannot apply.
We have some serious problems with section 26 of the Unemployment Insurance Act. Less than 3 per cent of the people who receive unemployment insurance receive training under section 26 of the act. It is less than 3 per cent.
I have numerous letters from various constituents and which I will be referring to, I would like to refer to one at this point. I will not name people because I do not want to embarrass anyone. There are some very proud people in my constituency, as I am sure there are in everyone's constituency. I do not want to embarrass anyone. However I will give the letters to Hansard if it is necessary.
This man applied for UIC in January 1991 and at that time asked if there were any programs available for upgrading. He was told that in his case there were not
Government Orders
because all the seats that were available under section 26 of the Unemployment Insurance Act were taken.
He asked: "What if I take a course myself? Would I be all right? Would I be within the law?" He was told: "No. If you take any courses on your own during the day, during the time that you are supposed to be looking for a job, you will be disqualified". He decided to take upgrading night courses by correspondence and proceeded to do so.
That was not the big problem. The big problem was toward the end of his benefit period when he got a notice saying: "Please come to the unemployment office, the CEC office. We may be able to help you in getting some education, some upgrading and some help to assist you in finding a job".
He went to the unemployment office at that point and said: "If it is available now, why was it not available then?" By the time he went through the whole process of assessment and finding out what it was he wanted to pursue, his benefits terminated. He no longer qualified and he fell on to welfare. That is one case where the system failed an unemployed worker.
We hear statistics about the number of people who are unemployed in Canada. Somewhere in the neighbourhood of 1.5 million is the figure that is being thrown around these days. It is thrown around very loosely and sometimes very callously.
The reality is that the 11 per cent, the 1.5 million people we hear about, are only people who are receiving benefits. We do not hear about the other million or so who are on welfare, who no longer qualify for UI benefits, who no longer qualify for retraining. They fall between the cracks of the system.
The government clouds the issue by not including those numbers when it says that the statistics are x per cent of people unemployed. The government and all of us in this House as part of the Government of Canada- which we all are part of-have a responsibility to make people aware of what the real figure is and what the realities are out there.
As an aside to this discussion we also have a further responsibility to make these statistics known to our youth, to our young people. I have had too many young people come in my office in the last few weeks who have said: "I am no longer in school. I quit. I could not get along with the teacher. As a result of that, I am no

Government Orders
longer living at home. I have to go elsewhere because my parents said that if I did not go to school I would have to leave".
You start looking into what was the cause of all of these problems, why it all started, and why this kid is leaving school. It is both boys and girls. It is not just one. The reality in a lot of cases is that the parents cannot find a job. The mother cannot go out to work, the father cannot go out to work because there are no jobs. There are all kinds of problems in the house. They do not know where their next meal is coming from. They argue among each other. Kids are under a lot of peer pressure. They want to be like everybody else but they cannot because their parents do not have jobs. Their parents do not have jobs because they are being told that they are not smart enough and they need more training. The kids are suffering.
We have to do whatever we can. The government has a responsibility to do whatever it can to ensure that people get back to work.
When we talk about training, I think we have to put more emphasis on the fact that we need a parallel job creation program to go along with those training programs if the reality is that our work force needs retraining. I say there are jobs in Canada. There are opportunities for Canadians to go back to work. They did have skills before all these problems existed. They were working and they were functioning.
I do not think the government can sit back and say: "It is a global problem. We have to face the reality that it is not just a Canadian problem. It is a global problem". I agree with that. Maybe it is a global problem but does that mean we have to sit back with our arms folded and say: "I am going to wait until somebody else takes care of me; I am going to wait until somebody else comes up with a solution to my problems"?
I do not think we have that luxury. I think we have a responsibility to act for Canadians in this country. I do not think we have to sit on our duff and wait for Japan or the United States to come up with a solution. We have the ability right here to do that and that is what we should be doing.
We cannot shift the burden of responsibility on to someone else. The number of people served in my
community of Timmins-Chapleau, and in Timmins in particular, by the South Porcupine Food Bank is astronomical. That food bank serviced 6,000 families last year in a small community of 47,000 people.
These are people who could be working. We have a movement that was bom in Timmins called "Save Our North-Save Our Jobs", an excellent program with excellent ideas. They are not asking for millions of dollars in investment. They are asking for a caring government to listen, to realize that the basis of our wealth is our resources. Those resources are mining, forestry and fishing. They want the government to recognize that we have to continue supporting our resource sector because that is where our wealth is.
Why is it that this government will not act? Only a fool does not change his or her mind. There are no fools in this House; there are none sitting on either side. The government really believes that what it is doing is right. It really believes the road it is on is the road to the salvation of Canada, that it will cure the problems. That sure scares the heck out of me because the government really does believe it. It is not willing to listen to anyone else. Its policies are the only policies and it is not prepared to change anything. That is wrong.
There are numerous ideas out there. There are numerous people who have some wonderful ideas to help get us out of this recession and create some jobs, people like those involved in the "Save Our North-Save Our Jobs" program. Will this government listen? Will it do anything? No. It would rather sit back and say: "This is not the way to do it. This is what we are going to do. It does not matter what anybody else says. We are going to continue on this road".
I refer for a moment to a letter sent to me by the Timmins Chamber of Commerce. I will read it into the record because it is important and indicative of what other chambers of commerce and other people in the region are trying to do. It reads:
The Timmins Chamber of Commerce in association with the Timmins Economic Development Corporation will be applying to obtain the "Community Futures" designation in Timmins. Our high unemployment rate and present economic condition have made it critical for our community to obtain additional funds and programs to retrain our unemployed and encourage economic renewal for providing business incentives.
May 8, 1992

During these difficult economic times we would like to count on
broad support from various sectors in our community. We would like
to ask for your endorsement at this time in the form of a letter
addressed to the Timmins Chamber of Commerce by May 11, 1992.
I certainly do intend to send a letter of support for this initiative. I would certainly hope the government would also endorse it. These are the kinds of things we have to start looking at and we have to start realizing that we just cannot sit back and do nothing. We have to help.
I would like to turn just for a moment to something that came up during the debate by the Minister of State for Employment when she talked about an increase of funding for students for summer employment.
I would like to make reference to Toronto. The $100 million in cuts from Canadian Jobs Strategy will mean a reduction of programs in that area which provide job skills for women, young people, immigrants and the disabled. They will be reduced from 30 programs to 12 programs. That is only part of the story.
In Timmins it is very devastating when we consider we had applications for some 287 summer jobs for students. As a result of the cuts to the SEED program, we were able to accommodate 57 jobs. That is disastrous. Last year we received $238,000 of SEED money for the section in Timmins served by the Timmins CEC. This year we got 123,000 measly dollars.
How can any government member stand in the House and say that they are trying to help?
Students who would normally work during the summer to help pay for their education come the fall will be deprived of that opportunity because this government does not want to help.
Government members are probably going to get up and ask questions about where we would get the money or what we would do. We have to start looking at the reality. We have to start creating some jobs. Let us put the parents of those children to work and then the children would not be so dependent on SEED money. The solution to the problem is getting people to work. That is what we want. That is what Canadians want. They do not want handouts. They want to go back to work.
Government Orders
I have another letter from the Salvation Army. The Salvation Army has put in an application to Canada Employment National Management Services for funding support of a national employability co-ordination roll to promote the Canadian Jobs Strategy with business, labour and client groups, and to assist with the development of training projects in Salvation Army settings across Canada. There is another organization worthy of mention here because it is trying to do something. It is asking for assistance and is not getting it.
We need to place a lot of emphasis on the fact that people are out of work. We do not want to institutionalize food banks. We do not want to encourage people to go on welfare. We want to encourage people to work.
We have skills in this country. We need some development in the areas of those skills. We cannot teach fishermen to be miners. We cannot teach miners to be foresters. We cannot teach foresters to be fishermen. There are no jobs in those areas.
That is what this country is made of. Our industrial jobs have gone. They have gone south of the border and they are still going south of the border. If NAFTA goes through it is going to be even worse. We have to rely on the resources we have now. We have to rely on the skills we have now. Canadians are looking for jobs. They had jobs before this recession. Given the opportunity, they are very well skilled to go back to work.
I urge this government to take another look at the direction it is going. Yes, we need some training programs, but we need more job initiatives. We need more job programs, and I think that is the solution to the majority of our problems in this country.

Madam Speaker, I want to question the member on a statement he made last week, as reported by The Hamilton Spectator, in relation to the topic-and it is interesting we would be on that topic today-of welfare, unemployment insurance costs and the difficulties created by both. It reads:
In Hamilton to discuss problems in training programs, welfare and
unemployment insurance, Cid Samson (Timmins-Chapleau) said
the government should look into just printing the money they need
to spend their way out of the recession.
Then it quotes directly as follows:

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
"Instead of borrowing the money, we create it. We do not have to Let US discuss it. Let US not shout at each Other pay it back , he said during a meeting with aldermen Dominic because we are not going to solve anything, but that is his Agostino, Dave Wilson and Hob Charters.	way of doing business
He is suggesting that we just print the money, that we do not have to pay it back.
In relation to what the hon. member mentioned today in the House, he said that there are numerous new ideas and that we cannot shift the burden of responsibility on to someone else. He is suggesting new ideas, but the only new idea that I hear from the member to print more money.
Would he please explain who pays back the money that we print and what that does to the Canadian economy? I think all of us know, but can he actually hide behind that sort of NDP philosophy?

Mr. Speaker, anybody who knows me knows that I do not hide. The member should have read the preamble to that newspaper article in Hamilton. Yes, I was there and yes, I did say that.
In the preamble to that statement I said to the reporters that were there: "I am on very thin ice here. I do this without qualification. I say this off the top of my head, striving to reach a solution". What I said was: "When we borrow money what are we doing? We are going around in a circle. We are borrowing money today and we have to pay it back as we go, and so on. We are just creating a larger and larger problem. What might be a good idea is maybe we could just print the money". Who do we owe the majority of our debt to? We owe it to ourselves. Yes, some of our debt is offshore, but 67 per cent is owed to ourselves.
How much would you print?

How much would we print? If you will shut your mouth and put your ears in gear, you will know what I am going to say. I said in Hamilton to the reporters that were there, I said: "There is no amount. I do not have an amount. It is something that may be worthy of discussion". But that was not reported.
The point is that at some juncture in time we have to step back and take a look at where we are going. Are we going in the right direction. Is it something that is worthy of discussion? I think it is. The member obviously thinks it is because he raised it.

Madam Speaker, I would like to take the opportunity to ask the member a particular question that has somewhat eluded present governments in power and is the reason they have entered into a process of setting up labour force development boards in conjunction with the provincial labour adjustment board that we are all familiar with. One of the areas that I would like to ask the member to give his party's views on its perception of the future role of labour adjustment boards. How will labour adjustment boards deal with retraining for the future, the kinds of jobs that we in northern Ontario are very familiar with? That, for example, would be the mining industry where layoffs are occurring because of new technology, the effects of the prices of gold, and mining being cheaper and more profitable in other countries.
The other issue is the forestry sector where because of technology and changes and gluts in the pulp and paper industry there are massive layoffs.
I would be very interested in knowing what the NDP's position is on these national training systems that are being put in place and whether in fact he sees them as a catch-all and a way of training our employees for the foreseeable future.
When I get my opportunity to speak in a more in-depth manner, I will be talking about my views on that particular subject. I would be interested in knowing what the NDP thinks of it. The government has made a big to-do about new programs and new training regimes they are putting in place which will take up to 1993 to put in place. Of course we know the government has been in power since 1984.1 would like to know from the member what his party's views are on these new training regimes that are being put in place, particularly in Ontario.

Madam Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his question.
There is a need for training advisory boards to identify the needs in particular regions. Their function is to find out what the long-term needs are. As we look to the future at technological change and at processing in the mines and lumber industry, the labour training boards have a responsibility to explore ways of taking our
May 8, 1992

resources to the next step of completion. Rather than sending them offshore, they should be looking at ways of extending that process here in Canada, in northern Ontario. By doing that they should also be looking at ways of upgrading the skills of those people who have worked in those trades so that they can keep up with that technological change.
When we take someone in from the mining sector who has done nothing but mining for 25 years and put that person in another environment, it is a drastic change.
I think that part of the mandate of the board should be to look at ways of upgrading the skills of that particular worker within the field that he or she is most comfortable in. I think that can apply in all sectors of our resource industry.
There is a job that has to be done. I do not think that training boards can be outside the regions they are serving. I think they have to be from within the regions they are serving. Therefore we should keep local autonomy. We should keep local people involved because they are the ones that know best what is needed in those areas.
I think in fairness to the local training boards there is a function for them. I only hope that as time goes on this is the way they are going to develop and these are the directions they are going to be going.

speechtext: Are we resuming debate? I understand the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott- Russell will share his time with his colleague. He has 10 minutes.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am happy to take part in the debate today. I wish to congratulate the hon. member for Willowdale for proposing this motion in the House, a non-confidence motion against the government because of its failure to provide training and retraining initiatives for Canadian workers.
Government Orders
I look forward to the vote which will probably take place next Monday, a vote that will express the lack of confidence that members of Parliament, as well as the population in general have in this minister and indeed in the government as a whole.

In the throne speech of November 5,1984 the government said and I quote: "My government recognizes that measures to improve and expand skills training and retraining are essential elements of a sound approach to provide job opportunities".
The reality is that between 1985 and 1988 the Conservative government has cut total funding for job training by 30 per cent. The Canadian Jobs Strategy, for instance, had $1,096 billion in 1984 and 1985 and $1,122 billion in 1990. But in 1984-85 training expenditures represented .24 per cent of GDP. By 1989-90 this had fallen to .17 per cent. We are going backward in terms of the investment provided to retrain workers so that every time there is a slump in the economy they would not be stuck in the type of situation they are now in.
The minister of employment said on April 30, 1992, and I quote this from page 9921 of Hansard:
What we have obtained amounts to $400 million more money that
will be spent to train individual Canadians who become unemployed
in this year.
Mr. Speaker, you being the independent, objective and non-partisan person that you are in the chair, I am sure you will understand that information is, and I will put it kindly, grossly inaccurate. Figures show that under Bill C-21 the number is $302 million, not $400 million as the minister of employment indicated in the House on April 30, 1992. The increase for job training under Bill C-21 this year is $95 million not $400 million, and that $95 million that I have described is paid 60 per cent by employers and 40 per cent by employees from their contributions. In other words, the amount that the government itself has invested is simply not there.

I would now like to describe the situation in my riding of Glengarrry-Prescott-Russell. Some 1,511 people were out of work in the riding in 1990. One year later, in May 1991, the number of unemployed was up to 1,912. It is at 2,197 as of May 1992. These figures are much higher than those during the recession of 1982. I say to the government on the other side that in my riding the

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
present recession is much worse, contrary to what the government may be saying.
The number of unemployed in my riding represents 11 per cent of the labour force. I have just described the unemployment situation that is soaring. Now I shall give you some statistics on the amounts invested there in training. In 1991 the Glengarry and Prescott Employment Centre granted some $661,000 for integration and employment development as well as under the Unemployment Insurance Fund. That was last year. In 1992 while unemployment is rising, the amount dropped from $661,000 to $600,614. My riding got $60,000 less this year. Where is the minister coming from when he tells us that the government has increased its share of training costs?
Recently in my riding of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell the United Counties of Prescott and Russell wrote a letter to the Prime Minister of Canada. Here are a few quotes from that letter: "Prime Minister, at its meeting of last March 24, the Council of the United Counties of Prescott and Russell supported the recommendation put forward by its committee on industry, tourism, agriculture and trade in favour of the implementation of a financial program for the economic recovery of Eastern Ontario, similar to FEDNOR, a program designed for northern Ontario".
This is what I have been promoting in this House for the last two years. My colleagues, the members for Renfrew-Nipissing-Pembroke and for Stormont- Dundas, and I have raised that question time and time again in the House of Commons, asking for help from the government on the other side. I refer again to that letter signed by Jean-Pierre Pitre, director general and secretary treasurer for the United Counties of Prescott and Russell. He says to the prime minister than in preparing that recommendation, we have taken into account the following facts. First, the number of jobs lost and of industries closing in eastern Ontario; and, second, in certain communities in eastern Ontario, the unemployment rate is twice as high as the national average. The member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell is not the only one to have this opinion. The counties, the municipalities in my riding, say the same.
Third, some federal programs which served to help the creation of new industries in eastern Ontario, such as the Industrial and Regional Development Program, the IRDP and the federal-provincial agreement for eastern Ontario, have been abolished or simply not renewed. Fourth, the federal government has recently closed its regional development office for eastern Ontario.
We are in a recession and the federal government now chooses to close its regional developement office for eastern Ontario, which is located here in Ottawa. They do not seem to think, on the other side, that we have economic problems in Canada. Unemployment is at 14 per cent in Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, but they do not care. They will not do anything to help my constituents.
Fifth, the federal government is responsible for helping the social and economic developement of disadvantaged areas. Alleluia. The mayors, prefects and municipal councillors of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell are so right. It is - indeed the federal government's responsibility to provide measures for the social and economic development of our region which is far from advantaged.
The message to the other side is clear. They must act as soon as possible to increase the manpower training programs everywhere in Canada, especially in the riding of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, which I have the honour and the privilege of representing in this House. We need an economic renewal program. I have said so time and time again and I will likely have to say it again in order to convince hon. members opposite that our economy needs a boost. This mess we are in will not go away by itself. Other regions in Canada have programs, well good for them. It is well and good to have a FEDNOR program in northern Ontario, a Canadian Western Diversification Program, and a program for the Atlantic region, but, our region is at an unfair disadvantage. Therefore we too must have tools.
I would not want the President of the Treasury Board and others to think that because my riding is close to the Peace Tower, not far considering the size of our country of course, all is well in our area. Things are certainly not that great in the national capital either, but 50 miles away in my riding where there are problems in the textile, clothing, steel and other industries we need help, and we need it now.
May 8, 1992

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today I have the pleasure to speak on a motion whose purpose is to draw the government's attention to a most important ingredient for job creation and economic prosperity.
The motion before the House today is sponsored by my colleague from Willowdale and stresses the importance of job training and retraining initiatives and the government's abject failure to provide these key elements in order to put Canadians back to work.
This motion is asking members to condemn the government's total failure to provide good quality job training that is accessible to those in need and especially to those at the bottom of the social ladder.
I would like to demonstrate in the 10 minutes I have how this government has repeatedly promised concrete job training programs but has failed to deliver. I would also like to show members that whatever training exists is not necessarily accessible to all those in need.
First, the government must realize that it is responsible for the high unemployment rate that is crippling the country today. With the Canada-U.S. trade agreement, an over-valued dollar, an endless amount of tax increases, and a whole range of inept economic policies over an eight-year period, no wonder Canada finds itself in what is probably the worst recession in its history.
Over 1.5 million Canadians are without work. These figures fail to take into account those who have given up searching for a job. We heard this morning that statistics show 71,000 Canadians have left the work force because they have no more hope in the system.
In my home province the unemployment rate is 12.5 per cent which represents more than 475,000 people officially looking for work. The situation in the Montreal region is just as distressing where the unemployment rate is 12.9 per cent and where more than 206,000 Montrealers cannot find jobs. In fact, the Montreal region has been severely hit by this made-in-Canada recession.

The Montreal area represents nearly half the labour market in Quebec. This area is undoubtedly the motor of Quebec's economy. Unfortunately in this area live half of all the jobless in the province. Over 615,000 people, that is 21.5 per cent of the whole population of the metropolitan area of Montreal, live in poor households.
The question we have to ask ourselves is: How we will get rid of this blatant poverty and put people back to work? All in all there are many ways to do it.
This government should start introducing sound economic policies. With balanced economic policies, the government would create a climate of confidence and encourage businesses to create jobs. This would effectively encourage consumer spending which in turn would help boost the economy and create jobs.
In order that Canadians can avail themselves of these jobs the government must provide those people, the victims of modernization and economic crisis, with effective training programs. Many times the Tories have promised training and retraining programs to help Canadians cope with economic disruptions.
One of those occasions where Tories promised such programs was at the time of the trade talks with the United States.
In fact that promise helped the government gain support for the free trade agreement. I remember how firmly my province supported the free trade treaty because this government had promised to create appropriate retraining programs for the work force so that any worker displaced because of free trade could be retrained and hired in some other area.
Even as we speak now we are waiting for such programs. In the meantime the government is negotiating another free trade agreement, this time a trilateral accord including Mexico. As for us, we are still waiting for a program to provide training for our workers, for all Quebec and Canadian workers affected by free trade so that they can work in other areas.

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
In 1988 the government did not keep its promise. This morning we found out how many people are out of work, and no longer in the labour force. We are talking about 1.5 million people, not to mention those who are not included in the statistics since they no longer receive UI benefits and are on welfare. You have no idea how many property owners in my riding have come to me. They were able to buy a home after years of savings and sacrifice. But now they have lost their jobs, their UI benefits have expired, and they do not qualify for welfare assistance because they own a house. They are left with nothing. They live in poverty because they have a house. What does the system do for them? It penalizes them for having worked and saved their money all these years.
Let us turn to Bill C-21. Every time we ask questions about labour training the government blames us for delaying the adoption of this legislation. But why did the debate take so long? It was because it had to. I want to remind the government it has been two years now since we passed that bill. Where are the programs the government promised when it tabled this bill? Where are the programs that would give people a chance to receive training and find new jobs? Where are those programs? Where are the new jobs? In Montreal, the unemployment rate is around 13 per cent. It is easy for the government to blame the Liberals because we delayed the passage of Bill C-21. The bill was adopted more than two years ago and we are still waiting, just as we are still waiting for training programs to deal with the jobs lost as a result of the free trade agreement with the United States. We are still waiting for this program ever since Bill C-21 was passed two years ago.
I would like to add that because of this government, Canada is the only country, aside from the United States, that has stopped contributing to its unemployment insurance fund, and that is a serious matter, especially today. I would like to emphasize the importance of training programs. They are intended not only for unemployment insurance recipients but for everyone, anyone who wants to work, including young people who have finished university. They come to my riding office and they tell me they are looking for a job and that people keep telling them they need experience. Where will they get the experience if they never manage to get
that first job? That is the sad thing about our young people. They make sacrifices to finish their studies and once they graduate, they send out hundreds of thousands of applications, to be told they do not have any experience. And when they do have experience, there are no jobs. We must get out of this vicious circle and give young Canadians something to look forward to.

Mr. Speaker, in his speech the member did challenge the government's commitment to spending on training and on training adjustment. I want to review some of the numbers with him and I hope he will have a chance to comment on them to lay to rest some of the allegations he has made here this afternoon.
One of them of course is the fact that the minister himself has acknowledged that $100 million was cut from the Canadian Jobs Strategy program. I think it is important to put on the record, and the minister has mentioned this on many occasions, that there is still $1.6 billion of taxpayers' money in that program. That is worth acknowledging and I hope the member will acknowledge that.
For developmental uses within the minister's department the budget is up itself this year by $400 million. That is not an insignificant number and I hope he acknowledges that as well. An important statistic to remember is the net increase for training and adjustment is up by $300 million this year.
I hope the member responds to those numbers. We can play with the numbers all we like but at the end of the day the fact is that we are spending more money, not less money on training and adjustment.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will try to use the hon. member's phrase "we can play with figures", but what is the reality? The reality is today we have an unemployment rate close to 12 per cent across the country. We have in one month 71,000 people who have left the work force. That is the reality. Plus we have 1.5 million unemployed Canadians looking for work. That is without counting the millions who have expired from the list and are on social welfare or have given up and I do not know where they are.
May 8, 1992

I want to remind the hon. member that when Bill C-21 became law the government withdrew from contributing to the unemployment insurance fund which until then was being financed by employee, employer and government contributions. In that period the contribution of the government was about $3 billion. We were still benefiting from economic growth. Let us not forget that the economy was good in 1985, 1986 and 1987. The government withdrew from that contribution.
Perhaps I should ask the hon. member what happened to the $3 billion that the government took away from the unemployment insurance fund. Not only did the government save that $3 billion, but because of its withdrawal it asked employees and employers to raise their contributions over 30 per cent from July 1991 to January 1992.
The government says it is putting money into training. Yes, it is putting in some money, but $3 billion was in the system. The government did not need the money because we had good economic growth. If the government had left the money in the fund it could have put it into training to prepare us for the free trade fiasco and for whatever modernization that we need in the labour force.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Richardson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Transport):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be taking part in debate on this very important motion today. With due respect, however, to the hon. member's motion, I think it indicates he has not looked very carefully at the government's programs to help Canadians during these tough economic times.
I want to assure hon. members that this government is deeply committed to assisting Canadians and to getting our economy rolling again. In doing so I think we might respond to some of the questions just posed by the hon. member for Saint-Leonard. I know my colleague from New Brunswick was anxious to do that so perhaps in my remarks I will be able to respond to some of the questions just raised by the hon. member for Saint-Leonard.
The Department of Employment and Immigration is still well aware that it is essential to give Canadian workers every opportunity to help this great nation compete in an expanding global economy. We are the catalyst for the private sector to play an increasing role in promoting, training and lifelong learning. These are vital elements to meet the challenge of ensuring that we
Government Orders
have a productive work force during the remainder of this decade and into the 21st century.
To that end, opposition members should be aware the federal spending for worker adjustment has grown significantly. For the 1992-1993 fiscal year, for example, we have allocated $3.4 billion. This is almost 60 per cent more than the $2.1 billion spent in 1985-1986.
During our eight years in office this government has done more to instil a sense of pride in being a productive citizen than any previous government.
Let us take a look at the creation of the Canadian Jobs Strategy in 1985. This EIC initiative has emphasized job oriented skills development and, as never before, paid special attention to women, aboriginals, visible minorities and persons with disabilities. We know the strength of Canada comes from drawing upon the skills of all of our citizens.
During the past two years EIC has gradually brought in a new employment programs and services framework. It is comprised of four new programs: information and special initiatives, employability improvement, labour market adjustment and community development. Together they consolidate all the elements of the Canadian Jobs Strategy which has a budget for 1992-1993 of approximately $1.6 billion.
In 1989 EIC responded to a rapidly growing need for a highly skilled labour force by introducing a labour force development strategy. We followed it up in 1990 by amending the Unemployment Insurance Act so more UI funds could be used to train unemployed workers.
The UI safety net is still there for people who truly need it but now the system has been transformed from strictly passive income support to an active re-employment strategy. We have increased expenditures for training and other active measures from $500 million in 1990 to $1.8 billion this year. That is a 260 per cent increase in active support for workers in our country.
As well, our work sharing program enables UI funds to be used to avoid layoffs. It means that during work slowdowns employers are able to retain their workers. For example, take a company that manufactures engines in Winnipeg that anticipated having to increase layoffs until it heard about work sharing. Instead, employees work two to four days per week, share available work and collect UI benefits for their days off. They could also use their days off for training. It makes a lot of sense. Work

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
sharing is a $100 million government program that works and it keeps Canadians working.
Another important element of the government's approach is the claimant re-employment strategy. This is a program designed to give even more help to UI beneficiaries through increased counselling and job search assistance with a view to getting workers back to work.
By moving to more client oriented programming Canadian Employment Centres and EIC's labour market partners have additional flexibility to adjust EIC programs to local requirements.
The hon. member's motion offers the preposterous notion that we have failed to provide job training and retraining. Tiy telling that to the 639,000 potential workers who received assistance last year in Canada and the 650,000 who will receive employment and training assistance this year. We also have an arrangement with provincial governments whereby we purchase classroom training in various trades from provincial institutions. In addition, EIC gives four-year grants to help provincial institutions set up co-op education programs.
I know that all hon. members are well aware of our stay in school initiative which is a program for young people at risk of dropping out of school. Young Canadians at risk of not fulfilling their educational potential would short change themselves and short change the Canadian work force.
It is no secret that this government believes in partnership. There is the partnership I just spoke of with provincial governments and there is the partnership with the private sector groups. The people at the grassroots are in the best position to know what training is relevant to the needs of their communities.
Since 1985 we have been providing more EIC funds to private sector organizations which, in turn, purchase courses. The result is that taxpayers get more for their dollar because private sector groups are often able to negotiate better prices. As well, training institutions are
more responsive to market forces because they are competing for federal dollars.
Employment and Immigration Canada's industrial adjustment service is second to none when it comes to lending a helping hand. This service is a co-ordinating tool or a facilitator. It promotes efforts in business and labour to find workable solutions to industrial problems.
I am sure that all hon. members appreciate that rapid changes in technology create uncertainty and insecurity among workers who have to adjust fairly quickly. Under an IES agreement, the implications for training in a new technology are managed successfully.
In 1989 the government asked the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre to co-ordinate an extensive series of consultations on the future of our human resource development and labour market programs. Those consultations with the people of Canada gave us a broad range of recommendations on how to reform our labour market policies. We learned that the government must give the private sector a more direct say in the use of our federal resources to address labour market problems.
We also learned that the private sector must put more time, effort and resources into developing a skilled, competitive work force.
Simply put, we realize the necessity of forming partnerships committed to effective labour market development. With that knowledge we established the Canadian Labour Force Development Board which was announced in January 1991.
Hon. members will recall that the board is comprised of 22 leaders from business, labour, education, training institutions and social action groups. This independent body determines its own priorities and hires its own staff. The board's first major undertaking in fulfilling its mandate was to recommend the 1992 UI development uses expenditure plan. This is an extremely important step. It means that the partnership is working. It sets out the tone for a productive relationship between the public and the private sector in speeding up the training and adjustment activities of unemployed workers.
The plan's success marks the beginning of a new era of co-operation in which Canadians are consulted about decisions that affect them. In the past the private sector has not had a clear role in labour market development.
May 8, 1992

This government is now drawing upon private sector expertise in a way that will enable business, labour and individual communities to play an integral part not just at the national level. We are now negotiating agreements with provinces and territories that will result in the establishment of provincial and then local boards to further enhance the government's labour force development strategy.
These new boards will not duplicate the existing services of Canada Employment Centres and sectoral groups. Where appropriate, they will complement these bodies by drawing upon their knowledge of individual communities while focusing on training for unemployed workers and encouraging increased training for employed workers.
The government is justifiably proud and excited about these initiatives. We are extending private sector input, not by imposing policy on the labour market, but by allowing the process that establishes local boards to be driven by the labour market itself. The national board, provincial and territorial groups and the federal government provide guidance and support.
The government's prosperity initiative will further broaden the foundation already established by these EIC programs. The focus of our prosperity initiative is competitiveness and learning. Particularly significant is our comprehensive investigation of components associated with learning and skills development. I am referring to things such as basic and higher education, apprenticeship, school to work transition, vocational training, co-operative education, skills training in the workplace and national occupational standards.
Our goal is to establish a blueprint for the development of a learning culture in Canada. This is a blueprint to which all stakeholders can subscribe. It is a framework for a lifelong process supported by all Canadians.
To that end, consultations were undertaken by a private sector steering group. The group's members reflect a broad cross-section of Canadians. In September it will produce a plan of action for governments, business, labour, academics, scientists and ordinary Canadians.
Government Orders
Several hundred town hall meetings have been held in communities across Canada. The steering group is consulting with national associations and seeking individual expertise. Cabinet ministers are meeting with representatives of their client groups. I can assure hon. members that the input for this prosperity initiative is not just with the government, it is widespread and being driven totally by the private sector.
This is an historic concept in federal policy. For the first time in Canada the key is genuine partnership. We are working together to develop programs that will directly affect our lives and ensure that Canada has a solid, competitive labour force to take us into the 21st century.
The reason for this undertaking is simply that the government fully understands that the future economic health of this great nation depends largely on our ability to compete internationally. That ability will be determined by the levels of our skills and education.
We are about to undertake an experiment to determine if an earning supplementation system would be a good idea for some people on social assistance. The idea is based on the premise that some people remain on social assistance, not because they do not want to work, but because what they are capable of earning is too low to meet the needs of their families.
The experiment will be a five-year pilot project assessing feasibility and cost effectiveness. Those eligible will be employable social assistance recipients who are sole earners with at least two dependents. Participants will receive counselling and job search assistance as well as earning supplementation for up to three years.
At EIC we have great hopes for the outcome of this project. If successful, it will guide us in developing a more comprehensive and coherent social security system.
These are just some of the many successful ventures taking place because this government has had the foresight to realize that Canadians want to work. They do not want to sit around and do nothing. They want the opportunity to develop skills necessary to function in the work place of the 1990s. They want assistance that will enable them to be fully participating members of their communities and Canada as a whole. That is what the policies and programs of this government are achieving.

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
They are calling for action. The mission of employment and immigration is to help people. Whether it is to find a job, train for a new position, collect UI benefits between jobs, our entire raison d'etre is to help Canadians participate fully in the economic, social and cultural life of our nation and we are doing that. No previous government has ever made the efforts this government has made to develop a strong and proud work force among the people of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the member said in his remarks that the Canadian Jobs Strategy is paying special attention to women and visible minorities.
I would like the member to explain what his government is going to do then about the following government created barriers which actually actively discriminate against immigrant women. I would like to list a number of them.
First, the cuts of $100 million to the budget for CJS in this year's budget will, it is estimated, decrease training opportunities for immigrant women by 35 per cent.
Second, the lack of accreditation for women who come from other countries means that they either stay at home or they are forced to take jobs with very low wages. This means that Canada is losing the potential skills of many very well-educated professional women.
Third, I would like to ask the member to pay attention to the fact that money was allocated by the minister of employment, which I think comes to about $160 million, for language training programs for instruction to newcomers to Canada. This offers basic language training and the money is used to buy spaces. This sounds good, but the problem is that immigrant women cannot use this program because there are no training allowances that go along with it.
This means they do not have money to support their families or to even cover the cost of going to classes. Therefore it makes that program inaccessible to immigrant women. Immigrant groups right across the country are very concerned about this.
The fourth point is that the Employment Equity Act shows that visible minority women earn less than other women, so there is discrimination there.
