Also, there are two areas in particular that offer traditional job opportunities for immigrant women, that is the textile industry and the domestic workers industry in Canada.
We find now that vast numbers of immigrant women in the textile industries are losing their jobs because of the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement. At the same time the minister of immigration has brought in new very restrictive policies that have raised the educational requirements for domestics who would come from other countries. This, in effect, excludes many women from Third World countries.
All these policies, which are government policies, deliberately discriminate against immigrant women. I wonder if he would explain this. I also wonder what he as a government member of Parliament would undertake to do to help remove these barriers.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the hon. member's concern. These are concerns that she has raised before and I welcome them. I have had similar questions raised by constituents in my own riding. What we need to look at and understand here is that we are in a changing society. We have a lot of new immigrants coming into the country.
I appreciate and I think the government understands the concerns, particularly with some of the areas that the hon. member has mentioned, such as immigrant women coming into the work force.
We have been dealing with members who are currently in the work force, members who have not been able to maintain a skill level to allow them to continue to work in the work force, the veiy reasons for some of the retraining programs that we have introduced and are continuing to support. It is the very reason for some of the programs I have just discussed with regard to partnerships with the provinces and within the community to assist in the retraining of these people.
The same obviously applies to new immigrants who come to Canada, particularly refugees without skills. I think a particular concern of the hon. member and one I share is the recognition of skills that in fact immigrants do bring to our country. We have to recognize these skills. It is a program that we are continuing to work on and hope that we can recognize these skills to adapt them to the Canadian marketplace so that those skills and trades can be recognized and used.
May 8, 1992

The member mentioned the Employment Equity Act. There are still concerns and we will have to continue to work in that direction. We have come a long way, as the hon. member I hope will see and appreciate, in the past seven years with regard to employment equity.
I wanted to comment too, because it is one that has come to my attention in my own constituency, on her concern with regard to the use of domestics, particularly immigrants as domestics and some of the new regulations. Yes, we understand. I think we have to be very careful in this area though that we do not encourage the exploitation of domestics in our country, that is the bringing in of immigrants and underpaying them because of their immigrant status.
Our notion and the intent of government policy is to make all Canadians equal. Once they become Canadians they are all equal despite their background or from whence they came. It is not our intention to encourage the exploitation of women as domestics in Canada. I think that the minister has taken an appropriate direction to prevent that type of exploitation.

Mr. Speaker, further to the point I raised earlier, will the member undertake to talk to the minister about providing training for immigrant women who want to get into language instruction for newcomers program.
Will he ask the minister if they can please consider providing training allowances so it will be possible for women to use this program? Otherwise, it is sheer discrimination.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not sure I accept the premise of the hon. member's question.
I am aware that the new policy opens language training to a wider spectrum of clients, including those who are not immediately destined to the labour market. The wider eligibility recognizes that all immigrants need Canadian language skills to successfully integrate into our society.
The government will continue to make language training available to those clients who are in need the most and who are more likely to experience barriers to integration such as the hon. member has suggested. We are talking about women, disabled immigrants, visible minorities immigrants, persons with illiteracy disadvantages and refugees who may have traumatic experiences.
Government Orders
I am a member from Calgary and I am very aware of the influx in refugees and that Canada has opened its heart and arms to welcome these people who have no place to go. We have taken our share in Canada. It is incumbent upon us to allow these people to enter the work force. We need to improve our language training. The minister should be applauded for the new policy on language training programs.
I appreciate the hon. member bringing it to the attention of the House and to Canadians. It is a great policy of the minister and it will allow these people to become productive members of society. Language training is clearly one. We have to continue and as the hon. member suggests-
You are not allowing them, they cannot get in.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext: Yes, it applies across the board. We are encouraging women immigrants as well.

Mr. Speaker, needless to say, it is a pleasure to rise and speak on this particular opposition motion. I do not think any of us on this side take pleasure in criticizing the government. Contrary to popular opinion, we like to work with the government. In fact we are probably the most positive party in the sense of trying to work with government to see that it comes forward with good, proper legislation, with good programs, programs that are going to accomplish something.
Regretfully we find ourselves today having to rise and speak on this particular issue of training and retraining and unemployment because the government's record is abysmal. It has not accomplished anything in this particular area. As you look at the motion, it is the second part of the motion that is the critical part. It is because the minister has been involved in continuing to provide this House with incorrect, inaccurate and ambiguous information. It leads people astray and into thinking that things are well and functioning properly.
We all know from the people who call our constituency offices and the people that we meet from day to day that that is not the case. We only have to look at the fact that 18 per cent of Canada's manufacturing jobs were lost between January 1989 and March 1992. This government said during the free trade debate that we should not worry about that. It was going to put forward programs, retraining programs and a safety net in order to rescue

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
those people who suffer the adverse consequences of the free trade agreement.
Then it comes up with another dummy commission that says: it is not necessary. Talk to that 18 per cent who are out walking the streets in Toronto, in Moncton, New Brunswick, and in Victoria, B.C. You will see what they think about the government and its safety nets.
We hear the government and the minister say they have put more money in retraining and all sorts of things are going to be happening as far as retraining is concerned. Then you look at the facts. You find out that 1989-90 to 1992-93, the government cut its expenditures on training by $217 million.
How much?

Two hundred and seventeen million dollars. It is a shocking number, considering that we are going through a recession and that the ranks of the unemployed have swelled to such a level. The government says: "We are interested in retraining. We are involved. We are going to see something is going to happen".
What it does, and I can see by the look on your face, Mr. Speaker, that you are upset about it, is cast the responsibility on the employer and the employee. The government did not maintain its full responsibility. Imagine, there is $500 million being spent by the employers and the employees. If the Government of Canada had maintained even its commitment of $217 million, what a job could be done now here in Canada to help people retrain and get ready for the new economy and the competitiveness that the government talks about.
Instead, it backs out. It casts the responsibility on another group. While I realize this is not totally related to the debate, Canadians are having the biggest problem with this government in a similar area. In my riding we had three Ministers of National Defence come and promise us that they were going to build a new $100 million supply depot and that those 400 people in Moncton would keep their jobs. They did not need to have any concerns at all because here was a government that was here to help them. What happened? It cancelled the project. It said: "Tough luck to you folks. You are out of work". That is what it did. Then it tells the Canadian people: "Trust us. We are with you. I am from the government and I am here to help you".
What we have done in Moncton is not tell anybody what other government jobs we have for fear they will all be taken away from us.
We see it also in the area of student employment. In my riding and in the whole southeast part of New Brunswick, the program Challenge 92 has been cut by 12 per cent. Over 100 student jobs have been lost in my area because of underfunding.
They do not care abut jobs.

They do not care about our youth and our students: GST on books, increased tuition costs, increased residence costs for students. Do you know what the minister said publicly? He said: "The member from Moncton is playing politics. In fact, we have increased the program by $3 million and the Moncton area is doing very well".
Lo and behold, thanks to an investigative journalist who asked his officials what was going on, the officials confirmed that 12 per cent had been cut from the budget of southeast New Brunswick for student employment so that they could go back and train or retrain and pursue secondary and post-secondary education.
That is the commitment this government has made for training and retraining. Then it wonders why people in Canada are a little cynical about this government's commitment to training. There is no commitment to training. There is a commitment to get other people to try to train but there is no commitment by this government to train.
It is true and it is a shame.

It is. It is a crying shame. The member for Willowdale is upset and I can understand why. He does not bring forth these motions and chastise the government for no reason. There is justification for this type of motion. It is why we in this House have to debate these issues. I am sure that members opposite will rise and speak in support of this motion as time goes on, although we have not seen it thus far.
I know the minister and the premier of New Brunswick are announcing a new initiative in New Brunswick today, talking about training and retraining and the things that are going to happen. I hope those things work because we on this side are as committed as the government's
May 8, 1992

words are committed to training, retraining, re-education, and restructuring our economy and our work force.
Premier McKenna said it best, and I quote: "The foundation of this new agenda must be the three Es, education, economy and the environment. The three go in lock step. We cannot be competitive and economically successful if we are not properly trained for the world we live in". That is the nub of the issue and that is what this government opposite talks about but never does. It is the commitment we have to make to Canadians and not just words but actions and deeds. Not words like: "Do not worry about the free trade agreement. We will put in protections for you". Not words like: "We are committed to training" and then cutting the budget. Not words like: "We are going to provide projects to your community" and then announcing that those projects are cancelled. Not words like: "We are going to increase the budget for student employment programs" and then behind eveiy-one's back cut them. We want to see those positive commitments made to our education system, positive commitments to training, and those types of programs.
We are saying to this government: Shame on you. It is unusual for us to be so critical but it is absolutely necessary in this particular case that we rise in our place and say enough is enough. It is about time they did something for Canadians rather than looking at a warped sense of government and its role.
Good speech.

Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure today to speak to the opposition day motion presented by my colleague from Willowdale. This motion is important because it allows us to talk about the adjustment programs and the training that is necessary to be competitive in the global market.
As you well know, the debate in 1988 dealt specifically with one particular subject, the free trade agreement. In the debate during the election it was made obvious to us and all Canadians that the government of the day was prepared to enter into an agreement knowing full well that there would be some difficulties with it. In order for those difficulties to be made less severe for employees in particular sectors of the economy there would have to be some adjustment programs.
Government Orders
Let us take a look at where we have been and, most importantly as we talk in this debate, where we will go. In 1991 the UI account paid out a record $17.7 billion in benefits. It is important for us to reflect on just how much money that really is. It is 11 per cent of our work force, 11 per cent of those who are physically looking for a job. That does not include the large percentage of those out there who are not looking for a job because they have given up hope. There is a large percentage of people who are not contributing to the economy of Canada and who are not contributing to the future of our country.
Not too long after the election people on this side of the House, and in particular our party, said to the government: "All right, you have your free trade agreement. We know the effects. We know dam well that it is going to hurt a lot of employers and a lot of employees. What are we going to do about it? How are we going to help ourselves to be more competitive, to put in programs, put in training regimes that will in effect look after the future under this new, perceived global economy that everybody talks about?"
It is now 1992 and we are being told by the government that it is entering into a new process, a new regime if you will, that will put in place those adjustment programs for which we have been asking the last almost four years. I talk of course about the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and the strategies that it is undertaking.
I want to talk a little bit about the Labour Force Adjustment Board and the long-term job strategy of the government.
As we all know, there are certain sectors of our economy that are very important to make the engine of this country run. These sectors, and I will just name a few, are not all inclusive: forestry, the automotive sector, the fishing sector, the tourism sector, the mining sector and the high-tech sector that we are trying as a country to get off the ground.
The Labour Force Development Board's strategy and the paper that was put forward by the minister in this place suggested that with this new board we would have 22 individuals who would go throughout the regions and create local labour adjustment boards. Those particular boards would have the ability and the wherewithal to put

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
together strategies and positions on how we are to be globally competitive.
At the same time the government suggests that we are going to change our education system somehow, even though it comes under provincial jurisdiction, through co-operation with the provinces in order for us as Canadians to deal with the 30 per cent illiteracy problem we have, to deal with the people who are unskilled in certain sectors of the economy and so on and so forth.
That is all very well and good and I commend the government to a certain extent for putting forward some sort of initiative because I think it is important to give the people some hope. That hope is that governments which are in place, no matter what their political ideology, know what they are doing, know what they are talking about, and know the direction they want us to go. However, I have a bit of a problem with that. It has to deal with the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and the particular ideology of the government and just where we are headed.
According to the government and the people who are running this particular new board, the local training boards are to accomplish two main objectives and I want to read just one for you: "The main objective is having Canadians decide their own needs at a local level and getting business, labour and other groups to co-operate in the programs".
That is very nice, but the fact remains that that is not the issue at all. The forestiy sector, which is a national industry, has a tremendous amount of potential but also at the same time a large competitive advantage in certain markets and competitive disadvantages in others. This particular sector of the economy needs an industrial strategy not local training needs. Once the paper mill in Kenora where I live and grew up shuts down, it is all well and good to suggest that we will put a labour adjustment committee together, that we will have the local committee retrain all these employees.
That is not what we want. We do not want to have to deal with the problems after the industry is shut down. We want to deal with them while the industry is the strongest in the world and we want to make sure that the industry stays the strongest industry in the world. If we
are going to be in a global market, what is the sense of having labour adjustment programs to deal with shutdowns after the fact?
I would like to see, and I hope the minister is listening very closely to this, a long-term job strategy for the key sectors of our economy that make us the world leaders in those particular sectors. We need to deal with forestry in a comprehensive way and at the same time take the labour adjustment committee at the national level, break it down sector by sector, put together a strategy for that sector so that we do not have to go through the same thing we go through every 10 years. We have a boom and then we have a bust. Now we are in the period of a bust in the forestry sector where we have a 20 per cent over-capacity in the pulp and paper industry.
To me, this is just poor planning. We cannot continue to allow our sectors, our industries, to put themselves in positions where on the one hand they are creating a whole lot of jobs and on the other hand, because of free market forces, without any plan with the help of the government, dealing with the massive lay-offs we are dealing with now.
I have another example. I have a mine in my riding owned by Placer Dome, a very well-to-do company, I thought. The mine that I refer to is Campbell Lake, probably one of the world leaders in the production of gold. In the last four years that mine made a profit of $202 million. A week and a half ago the management of this mine decided without telling anybody in the town of Red Lake and Golden that they were going to cut 99 employees, wham, just like that, without even having the courtesy of telling the councils in those particular regions they were going to terminate 99 employees. It just happened. That is what I am talking about, planning.
If someone is going to make those kinds of business decisions, which they have a perfect right to do under certain circumstances, they have a moral obligation to the community to let us know what they plan on doing in the long term, in the future. That is what we are talking about here, the future.
If they think this Mickey Mouse Canadian Labour Adjustment Board is going to hand out dollars to individual communities and is going to look after the problem then they really are missing the boat.
May 8, 1992

The boat I want to be on is the one that has a strategy to deal with competition in Germany, the United States and Japan and to make sure that Canadians are at the leading edge of those industries.
If we can do that then we have done a job as a government. We need the right climate. We need the proper legislation in place so that we do not make it difficult for these companies to compete. At the same time those companies have to help us as parliamentarians and as governments. We are here to help the people and the corporations be the best corporate citizens they possibly can.
I hope the government realizes that this band-aid solution is a long way from the realistic solution that I am looking for.

Madam Speaker, it is an interesting debate today and I am pleased to take part in it.
We have covered quite a bit of philosophical territory in this debate and there are differing opinions obviously as there always is in this House. I think there is some commonality among us as well. I do not think there is any question in the minds of all of us in the House about the fact that Canada is caught up in a very changing world and to remain as we are is not going to be the way to approach the 1990s and the turn of the century. We cannot remain static. I think all of us agree on that.
I will begin on a positive note. I am going to refer to the United Nations study that was released a week or so ago. I think most of us in the House are very pleased with that study. It is certainly a pleasure as a Canadian to get to my feet and talk about it. Canada was identified by the United Nations as the best country in the world in which to live.
As we all know the report measured the quality of life for a citizen of this country and the citizens of 162 other countries in compiling the data. At the end of the day Canada came out on top, number one. As most of us know a year ago we were number two, exceeded only by the Japanese. I think most of us are very pleased with that finding.
What we have to remind the Canadian people is that despite the fact that we are number one in the world we still have difficulties as a country; we are not perfect and
Government Orders
we have to strive to make it a better country. That is the importance of this debate today. We have to strive to improve ourselves. There is some indication that we are making some progress. We probably will not make it as fast as we would like to see but despite the fact that we have difficulties we are making progress and that progress is evident in the report released by the United Nations, that indeed it is a pretty good country.
Let us focus on some of the things that are happening right before our very eyes and see what we can do to improve as a country. We are famous for throwing statistics around here fast and furious, and trying to sort them out sometimes is a problem. Some of those statistics which face us in this country are startling. They have been brought out in the competitive study, the Agenda for Prosperity Initiative, of the Minister of Employment and Immigration and the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology. That particular study and some of the cross-country community talks that they are holding brought some of these statistics forward.
I think it is worth mentioning some of these. One of these statistics is that one million students, which is 30 per cent, will drop out of high school this decade unless they are encouraged to finish school. We all know that education is a provincial responsibility constitutionally. We also realize for probably the first time in a long time and possibly the first time ever that governments have to work more closely to improve on that number.
Now is the time to talk about that more than ever as we go through our constitutional rounds. That is a very scary number. It is alarming because we have also heard that nearly two-thirds of the new jobs in this decade will require more than 12 years of education and training and 40 per cent of them will require 16 years or more of training.
Yet it is pointed out that 60 per cent of our current work force has no more than a high school education. It also points out that a 1990 survey concluded that 40 per cent of Canadian adults could not read or do math well enough to perform common, everyday tasks. Most startling of all, of course, is only one in three Canadian firms provide formal staff training.
Again, when viewing the global picture our statistics are better than some and worse than others. But there is much more that we have to do, not only the provincial governments but also the federal government, to improve those numbers and to face those realities. What

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
we do know is that other countries are doing that this very day.
The model that we often point to, of course, is the Japanese because they have realized for a long time that productivity is improved through education. They do not leave education, training or retraining solely up to governments. Industry does a great deal of it and somehow we have not done that in this country.
We cannot blame the corporations for that. But I guess it is a fact in this country that we have always assumed that governments will do it. Now for the first time we are realizing maybe there is a relationship that has never been established in this country between governments and business. Maybe it is time that they be given the incentive necessary to bring about some of this training to improve their own lot in the marketplace.
This becomes very clear when you look at Canada's competitive position. There is a very clear link between training, our ability to train, our competitiveness as a nation, and what we earn as Canadians from training with those very countries that we compete with.
Twenty-five per cent of our economy depends on trade with others. Although Japan out-trains us and out-per-forms us in the educational sphere, it is only 14 per cent of Japan's economy that depends on trade. In the United States it is only 10 per cent. Here we are two and a half times the United States in regard to trade and how much our economy depends on trade. Yet, our training falls very short of the mark. In fact, we are told that American industry spends twice as much as the Japanese on training. The Japanese spend five times, Germany eight times that we do on training in Canada.
We have to do more. But as the Minister of Employment and Immigration often points out in this House, we have to build a different relationship, a partnership with others to make it happen because governments cannot do it alone.
We have addressed the training problem as we have never done so in the past. One of the statistics of which the minister and all of us are quite proud is that that figure this year will exceed $3 billion to provide training and adjustment assistance for approximately 465,000 Canadians. If we include job training or job sharing in
this, over 600,000 Canadians were helped. The figure as I said will be over $3 billion, something in the order of $3.4 billion.
The question, of course, that the opposition raises is: Is it enough? I suppose in all honesty it is not enough and perhaps we should find more money. But that is the root of the problem itself. We know the burden of debt under which all the governments are operating today, federally, provincially and municipally. It is a question of allocating financial resources to do the job. Of course, we are limited in coming up with the dollars to do what we want to see done. I think a commitment by this government of $3.4 billion, given the finances of the Government of Canada, is not an insignificant figure.
The members who have spoken today, especially members opposite, have mentioned the changing dynamics of the Canadian economy. It is worth mentioning some of those changing dynamics here because not that we want it to happen, but some of these changes are happening before our very eyes often without our realizing it. But again it goes back to that need for further training in this country.
I read an article in Canadian Business magazine a few months back. I believe it was the February or March edition although I do not have the exact date. One of the things that was pointed out by a consulting firm is the fact that the Canadian economy is changing so quickly that some of us do not even realize the magnitude of some of the changes. I want to mention some of them.
One fact is that our electronics industry is now larger than our pulp and paper industry. This was before a downturn in the pulp and paper industry, I might mention. But how many of us actually knew that the electronics industry had surpassed the pulp and paper industry? Our communications and telecommunications industry is larger than our mining and petroleum industries combined.
More Quebecers work in the health and medical care industry than in the construction, textile, clothing, furniture, automotive, forestry and mining industries combined. More Albertans work in the financial services industry than in the oil and gas industry. More British
May 8, 1992

Columbians work in the communications and telecommunications industry than in the entire forestry industry.
Now those are startling revelations. We are moving beyond this notion of Canadians being the hewers of wood and drawers of water. And if we are going to continue to move in the direction we are, we have to sit down and determine whether we are doing the right things in regard to education and training.
Now let us talk about the dislocation in the Canadian work force which leads us into the free trade agreement, whether we did the right thing or the wrong thing. But let us talk about some of that dislocation within Canada in the manufacturing industry in this country and let us talk about some of those numbers and why they are happening.
It is happening. There has been a tremendous dislocation in the work force in Canada. Again in all fairness, we recognize that. But what we have to do to put this thing into context or frame it properly is to compare our Canadian position to that of our friends to the south of us, that trading partner of ours to the south, the United States of America.
What is happening in that country? It is true there has been a dislocation of workers in this country, but it is also true that they have a figure 10 times higher than ours in regard to dislocation of workers in the manufacturing sector in their country.
The first conclusion drawn is that, well, that is absolutely right. They have an economy that is basically 10 times the size of ours and they have a population that is basically 10 times the size of ours. We all agree with that. But I think the point we have to make here is that the dislocation in Canada has been no greater than that in the United States.
If that line of logic is followed, what has happened in the European countries is basically the same. The numbers of people dislocated within the industrial sector is simply because of these huge changes that are taking place within our economy, whether we want them to happen or not. If we are talking about 4.5 million people dislocated within the manufacturing sector in the United States that is fine. If we want to use a figure of 350,000 or 400,000 Canadians dislocated within the last number of years that is fine. I will accept those figures.
Government Orders
What we have to do is focus on why this has happened. It has nothing to do with our trading relationship with that country to the south of us. It has had a corresponding reduction in jobs in as well. Those job losses in Canada did not show up in the United States. So if we lost 400,000 jobs one would think the United States would have gained 400,000 jobs. William F. Buckley Jr. brought that out in a debate with Mel Hurtig.
There has been no increase in jobs in the United States. In fact, in some of its industrial sectors they are hurting worse than we are. Let us remove the politics from that argument because it is a false argument.
I can hardly wait for the member for Ottawa South to get up on his feet. We shared a number of months on the finance committee. It is not that we disagree on everything, but I am sure he will have something to state during the question and comment period and I will be more than glad to answer.
The truth is the dynamics of the Canadian economy is changing so quickly, so rapidly, that we have to move with it and move in ways that we can accommodate those Canadians coming on line and coming of age in regard to work, seeking a job for the first time whether they are leaving high school or university.
Our economy is changing very quickly and we have to be able to respond to it. I think we are doing that but if you want to examine whether we are doing enough, I would probably say we are not. Given the financial times we are experiencing in this country, we have nothing to be ashamed of.
Let us work together constructively to see if we can sort some of these problems and see if at the end of the day we will have a little bit again of commonality in our approach to this. We all want the same thing. We want a nation we can be proud of, we want a nation where our young people after leaving school can say that there is some opportunity there and all they have to do is go out and make it happen.
An article that appeared in The Globe and Mail yesterday speaks well of this subject in regard to attitudi-nal change in Canadians. In fact, young people and Canadians in general are saying that we do have to be competitive and we cannot as a trading nation remove ourselves from that equation even though we want to. I

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
mentioned the wealth that is generated in this country because of trade with other nations.
It is interesting to note as pointed out in The Globe and Mail article yesterday by Harvey Unchin that:
Three-quarters of Canadians believe competition leads to excellence and fully 90 per cent believe they cannot get ahead without taking risks. According to a study of Canadian attitudes more Canadians than Americans feel that the profit motive teaches the value of hard work and that few would strive to do their best if private enterprise were abolished.
That is interesting because it is a huge attitudinal change on the part of Canadians. As we have always realized, we have to go out and do it with our own two hands. We have to do it up here. We cannot rely on government to do it for us.
What we can do as government is put the structural changes, the foundation, in place that will ensure future generations will indeed inherit a good Canada.

Madam Speaker, having been invited by the hon. member to make comments I really could not resist the opportunity. As usual with my friend for Carleton-Charlotte I agree very much with what he said.
There was only one clear heresy that I heard in the course of his speech and that was the notion if Canada had lost jobs due to the FTA they should have shown up in increased jobs in the U.S. This of course is fairly ridiculous when you consider the concern we had expressed over the FTA was the economies of scale would favour the United States. Indeed without increasing the number of workers at all the ability of large U.S. plants to supply the Canadian market without any increased labour component would occur. That, in fact, is what we feared. That could well be the explanation for the fact that while plants have closed in Canada, particularly branch plants, that there has been no concomitant increase in work in the U.S. It was not necessary in order to supply the relatively small Canadian market from some of the huge U.S. plants.
That is something of a heretical aside. Many of the points he has made are valid concerning the need for Canada and the U.S. and all of the industrialized countries to recognize the fact that we are in a period of very significant change. I do find it surprising that he
needed to look to the prosperity initiative for some of the statistics he referred to since very similar numbers have been produced over the last number of years. This includes the very recent figures from the Economic Council of Canada which has, in the last few weeks, produced an excellent study on education, the dropout rate, the illiteracy rate and the numerical skills of Canadian high school graduates.
Unlike the prosperity initiative, the Economic Council was actually proposing some solutions. It was an agenda for change that governments both present and future could pursue in order to address some of the problems. Regrettably, of course, the government saw fit to shut the doors of the Economic Council of Canada so we will not be able to benefit from that foresight and those long-term perspectives in the future.
One suspects that sometimes the heat in the kitchen between the government and the Economic Council was just a little too great for the government so it was best to get rid of the Economic Council of Canada. This is a great loss.
On the specific issues that he raised with respect to training, I think it is important for all Canadians to understand that we do have to wrestle perpetually with this difficulty of mixed jurisdiction. The member raised that and perhaps I will conclude with this.
It strikes me that very often one of the frustrations that Canadians feel with politicians in general, and with Parliament, is their failure in dealing with the issues that critically concern them. I think of all of the issues that are lurking out there now which are quite apart from the ones that are immediate like the problem of unemployment and so on. It is this fear on the part of a broad range of Canadians that our educational institutions are failing us, that our children are not getting the training they need and that our workers who are being displaced by things that are outside of their control are unable to get retrained in ways that are meaningful so that they would be able to find jobs.
Instead of being able to deal with those very big and very broad problems, very often we, as members of Parliament, are caught in this bind of trying to figure out whether it falls within the federal or the provincial responsibility. How do we get the Council of Education Ministers together to work out a strategy? Is apprentice-
May 8, 1992

ship federal or is it provincial? How do we fund the universities and community colleges?
All of these issues must be seen by Canadians as missing the point. That point is whether we are able, as a country, to respond quickly to those challenges out there to enable our people to meet the challenges and to resume the tradition of prosperity that we have had the good fortune in this country to enjoy for 125 years.

Madam Speaker, I thought the member was on debate because he was so lengthy. There is a great deal to talk about in this debate.
I do sense that there is a common theme between us in regard to this. We will disagree on some of the specifics on occasion.
He did mention the FTA and whether it is good or bad.
I have studied economics as much as some in this House but less than others obviously. My belief has always been that a smaller nation or a smaller market has more to gain by selling into a larger market than vice versa. I think that is the beauty of the arrangement that we have with our neighbours to the south. The only thing that we have to do is be the best at what we do no matter what it is. That is what we have to learn as Canadians.
If we are talking about a strategy for the future, I guess it is the recognition, and more of us are beginning to recognize it, that we have to be absolutely the best in the world at what we do. I think there is a great deal of evidence out there that we are beginning to be the best in the world at what we do. Statistics bear that out.
It is also borne out by foreign investment coming into Canada. It is interesting to note that foreign investment in Canada right now is coming in at an all-time high. Foreign investors are now recognizing Canada as a good place to invest and recognizing that Canada has a trading relationship with the biggest single market in the world. We are a country that has come to grips with some of those fundamentals but we haven't completed it in its entirety. Statistics bear that out. For example, in 1991, 235 new businesses were established in Canada by first-time foreign investors. That is interesting. They tell me also that the projected capital expenditures by 1991 investors, over the first two years of their business, amounted to $2.1 billion. I think the proof is in the numbers.
Government Orders
We have difficulties in our trading relationships with all countries in the world because that is just human nature. I think what foreign investors and businesses are recognizing in Canada, however, is that we have a great deal of potential in this country of ours. We have the best work force in the world in terms of work ethic. We have a highly skilled work force, although we have more to do. We recognize that if we are going to compete with the rest of the world that we are going to have to do it ourselves. If we want to continue to have the highest standard of living in the world we have to do it ourselves. We cannot depend on someone else to do it for us.

Madam Speaker, this is what I want to ask the hon. member. If we are going to be the best in the world, and if that includes training, where does he suggest that the Atlantic provinces will get the funds to do that training in view of the fact that funds from the federal government have been cut back and in view of the fact that they do not have the kind of tax base they need to make up the difference themselves? Assume that training is key for competitiveness and we are in a recession. Also the Economic Council of Canada has pointed out in its summary on page 17 that the "employer based training effort is weak". The fact is that employers are not putting a great deal of money into training.
On the other hand, assume that the amount of training from the Government of Canada has been cut back except for those who are actually drawing unemployment insurance.
If competitiveness is important and if training is an important element in that, and if the Atlantic provinces are getting less and less money all the time to help firms do that training in a recession, how does he think training is going to take place? Where are the funds for it going to come from?

Madam Speaker, was it Mark Twain who said: "Lies, damn lies and statistics"? I think what the hon. member has to realize is that in Atlantic Canada, and in all of Canada, transfers to the provinces have increased not decreased.
I want to remind the member from Newfoundland that of the expenditures of revenues in his province by the provincial government, 50 per cent of that is transferred from the Government of Canada to the Government of Newfoundland. We have nothing to be ashamed of. We

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
have increased and not decreased payments to the provinces.
I want to put that correction on the record because I think it is very important that the people of Newfoundland recognize that.
In regard to training, the Government of Canada transfers to the provinces $6 billion for universities in this country. That is just one part of the equation. There are other moneys and other training areas that we transfer as well. I know we have nothing to be ashamed of with regard to transfers to the provinces. His province of Newfoundland benefits more from Confederation than any other province in this dominion.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to rise and participate on the Official Opposition's motion today on training.
This government has issued many written statements about equality for women and within these statements the correct assumption is made that training is an absolute necessity for women to reintegrate into the paid work force after raising children, for young women to launch themselves in an occupation with a future, for disabled women, for women on social assistance and for immigrant and aboriginal women.
The government states this in its own document Dimensions of Equality which is its work plan on women. It states it again very recently in the Estimates this year for Status of Women Canada.
In the meantime, though, it has cut $100 million from training programs that affect these very women the most. This is the second year in a row that it has cut $100 million.
In British Columbia, Manitoba and Nova Scotia, women's groups were told by Employment and Immigration officials that women were specifically targeted for cuts. They were told: "Women have had their day", "Women were done" and "Women have had their share over the last 20 years".
Women are still not fully integrated into a range of occupations in the paid labour force and that is because
of hundreds of years of job segregation, sexism and of lack of access to education and training.
Employment and Immigration seems to believe that 20 years is enough to reverse hundreds and hundreds of years of segregation even though in those 20 years men have always made up a majority of government-funded training programs.
Women's training programs across the country have been cut or told to completely change their client base to people collecting unemployment insurance. That cuts out the majority of clients for these services. The majority includes single mothers on welfare who are trying to find a job to support their family. They are not on unemployment insurance. I should add that the government says they do not deserve training or child care either.
The majority includes older women trying to re-enter or enter the paid work force for the first time after they have raised their children. The government is saying that these women are not worth bothering about according to this new policy.
The majority includes young women who are trying to break into the paid work force during the recession with no skills or job experience.
Who cares about them, Madam Speaker? This government does not say so. They do not care.
Farm women who need to find jobs outside the farm to make ends meet so that the family farm is not lost cannot get training because they are not on unemployment insurance.
The shift to training only, or primarily UI recipients, also hurts immigrants and refugees. They will not have access to training programs to integrate themselves into the Canadian job market.
Disabled women experience severe inequality in the job market and many have never been allowed to use their skills in paid employment.
These women are excluded from training programs.
Communities that are suffering the most such as aboriginal communities and black communities are ravaged by economic underdevelopment. The majority of

people in these communities is excluded from training programs.
You must have had a Ul-insurable job in the recent past in order to be able to collect unemployment insurance. This excludes contract and casual workers or people living in communities where there are no jobs.
From the time the Conservatives came to power in 1984 to the present government funding for training declined by 37 per cent in real terms. At the same time this government talks about training as a key factor in revitalizing the economy.
Over and over again in the speeches from the government side of the House we hear these buzzwords about competitiveness but where is the action on training?
It is no wonder we are in a recession, as are countries such as Britain and the U.S. Both of these are Conservative led countries.
It seems that Conservative governments cause recessions. Conservative governments spend so much time filling the pockets of their big business friends that they ignore the real people who make up the economy, those who work in businesses and those who buy the goods.
I want to talk about the death toll as a result of Conservative cuts. The following is a list of services which will be eliminated or radically altered to not serve those who need the services most. The list includes: the Women's Employment Counselling Unit in Vancouver; Career Action for Youth in Vancouver; the Counselling Resource Centre in Vancouver; Experience Unlimited, a program for older workers in British Columbia; the Surrey Job Centre for youth in British Columbia; Mosaic, a service for immigrants in Vancouver; Evolution, the only re-entry program for francophone women in Manitoba; New Options for Women in Moncton, New Brunswick; the Women's Enterprise Centres in Newfoundland; Seneca College's, Women into Trades and Technology program in Ontario; Working Skills for Women in Toronto; Focus for Change for low income women, in Toronto; Humber College's Career Planning for Women; Job Readiness Training and Career Planning for Immigrant Women will also be affected; Ontario's Dixon Hall STEP program for sole support mothers; First Step to Employment and the Bridging Program of the Working Skills Centre in Toronto have been cut by 100 per cent; African Bridging Program in Ontario
Government Orders
completely cut; Women Growing, a bridging program for women in conflict with the law cut 100 per cent; New Experience for Refugee Women; Wood Green Metro Youth Job Corps in Toronto; the Kingston Women's Self-employment Centre cut 100 per cent.
Young people, women, the poor, social assistance recipients, immigrants, refugees and racial minorities are the people this government has targeted for cuts. They are the people who need employment programs the most. In Toronto, Canada Employment Centres are turning away people looking for jobs who are not receiving unemployment insurance. This is not right.
This government is making poverty permanent. It is entrenching inequality in the job market so deeply that it will be almost impossible to come out of it. It dares to claim that it is doing anything at all to promote economic equality for women and minorities.
A leaked employment and immigration memo dated March 16, 1992 confirms what equity groups already knew. The Canadian Jobs Strategy is not fulfilling its obligations under the Employment Equity Act.
Participation rates for aboriginal, disabled and women workers have consistently decreased in these programs from 1987 to the present. The participation rate for aboriginal people was 8.8 per cent in 1987 and is 6.4 per cent this year. The participation rate for women fell from 42.5 per cent in 1987 to 39 per cent this year, although women make up 51 per cent of the population and almost 60 per cent of the poor. They are the vast majority of those in need of training programs.
The participation rate of the disabled decreased from 2.3 per cent in 1987 to 1.6 this year. The disabled make up 5.4 per cent of the paid labour force.
Female participation rates were never higher than 10 per cent in the government's job shortages program that focused on training people for skills that are in high demand. Related to the issue of cuts to disadvantaged groups in job training is the issue of gutting of job-related language training.
The new immigrant language training policy was introduced in January without input from immigrant and racial minority communities. The policy will take effect on June 1 of this year which is not enough time for meaningful consultation and a reworking of the policy.

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
This new policy means that immigrants who have been in Canada for more than one year will be disqualified from participating in the new language training programs. Canadian citizens will be excluded even if they are in desperate need of official language skills. Language Instruction for Newcomers to Canada or LINC, as it is commonly known, is necessary but certainly not at the expense of other language training. The criteria would focus on time spent in Canada, not on language needs. Another concern is the enormous waiting lists for language training. It is possible that many immigrants will never have the language training they require. By the time a space becomes available they will no longer be eligible.
The training allowance available to participants in English or French as a second language program will be discontinued making it infinitely more difficult for immigrants, especially immigrant women, to enrol in language training.
The short length of language training will render instruction almost meaningless. The new policy will limit the maximum length of language training to 24 weeks but only for those trainees at level 1, the lowest level of language competency. The level 1 means totally illiterate even in language from one's country of origin.
Since the majority of immigrants are beyond level 1, most immigrants will receive far less than 24 weeks training. That is not enough to become fluent enough in a language to effectively perform one's previous or new occupation or to further one's job training and education. It takes most people two years to learn a language. The government is proposing a few hours a week for as little as six weeks for many immigrants.
What is also worth noting is that immigrants will be tested at the beginning of a language course in order to place them at the appropriate level but there will be no follow-up at the end to make sure that they have acquired basic official language skills. This means the government is shielding itself from quantitative data about how its language training program is too short to teach people the basic skills they need.
Canada's immigration policy skims the cream of other countries in terms of those with education and lucrative skills such as doctors and scientists. Then it refuses to allow these people enough language training in order to
perform the jobs that they were chosen to come to Canada to do. The Conservative government is condemning immigrants with advanced skills and education to menial jobs. It condemns those without advanced skills in education to remain without skills and education. The people involved and their families lose, and Canada loses too.
The new policy will substantially lower the proportion of funds allocated to labour market language training. Only 20 per cent of funds will go to helping immigrants learn job related language and the specialized language they may need to find work in certain occupations. This represents a $76 million reduction in spending on job related language training in only two years. This Conservative policy keeps immigrants in ghetto jobs.
It is clear this government would rather have immigrants cleaning their homes and serving their food rather than working alongside them. The little funding there is for labour market language training will now be restricted to skills which are in demand. If someone was a doctor in their country of origin, but this is not in demand, they may have to become a hairdresser instead or whatever is in demand even though their skills and background are in something completely different. This is the logic this government uses.
The government should keep in mind that Conservative politicians themselves are not much in demand these days.
Language competency levels, tests and assessment tools have been developed without the input of those most affected, the immigrant women and men and the organizations which serve them. How can these tools be effective or credible without the input of those who know most about the situation, those who live in the circumstances?
Immigrant women who are not fluent in either official language cannot find good jobs with which to feed their families. They cannot make new friends and participate in the larger community and in political life in this country. They have difficulty interacting with the medical profession about their own health and the health of their children. They often cannot help their children with homework or communicate easily with their children's teachers. They have limited options in terms of finding out about their rights and have to rely on husbands or others in their community who in fact may
May 8, 1992

believe that their actions and knowledge should be restricted.
Battered and sexually assaulted immigrant women may not be able to find out about or use services for battered and sexually assaulted women. Language training may be the number one equality issue for immigrant women. Shutting immigrant women out of Canadian life does not help Canada and it does not save Canada money.
Canada is missing the skills, the intelligence and the talent of these new citizens. It is creating social problems, hurting women and their children, and creating increased costs for health care and other social services. Because of a lack of access to them at the preventive stage it leads to increased reliance on them at the crisis stage of a problem.
It encourages ghettoization of those who speak neither fluent French or English, not just in the job market but in Canadian society. Of course immigrants who speak neither English nor French will congregate together. Of course there will be serious problems if they are marginalized by Canadian society at large. Of course there will be misunderstandings, fear, and increased racism when people are unable to communicate. They are isolated from the mainstream of Canadian life.
Keeping immigrants and racial minorities poor and marginalized feeds into society's racism and is a direct cause of violence and instability.
The Conservative government, like its American friend and counterpart, will go down in history as a force that divided this nation and deepened the divisions along racial and socioeconomic lines. The Tory government cannot continue to ignore the expertise of immigrant and racial minority women when developing programs for these groups. The government cannot continue to punish and crush these communities without facing consequences.
Cuts in employment and language training programs, the delay of the Race Relations Foundation, the elimination of the Court Challenges Program render guarantees of equality in this country absolutely meaningless. Every day immigrants and racial minorities are faced with debasing racism in housing, in schools, in the job market and on the streets in our communities.
Government Orders
Words on a piece of paper will not help. Real and effective actions to promote equality is the only way to effect any real change. Programs designed by mainly white male bureaucrats in Ottawa, whose lives are totally cut off from the groups in question, do not lead to good policy. There must be real and meaningful consultation with the immigrant and visible minority communities.
During and after that consultation those views must be taken into consideration when policy is formed. Policies which deepen divisions destroy the social fabric of our country.

Madam Speaker, I would like to congratulate my colleague on a very eloquent speech on behalf of Canadian women and their need for job opportunities.
Earlier today I asked a government member what he and the government would do to eliminate the job barriers that immigrant women face, including an estimated 35 per cent cut in Canadian Jobs Strategy funds for immigrant women, lack of accreditation, the need for training allowances so that immigrant women can take advantage of available language instruction, the loss of jobs for immigrant women in the textile industry and restrictions now on women wanting to come to Canada as domestics.
The Conservative member gave no specific remedies he gave a lot of generalities. I would like to ask the member what she would do if she were in government.

Madam Speaker, I thank my colleague for Vancouver East for her comments and would add that this colleague is particularly well known throughout the Vancouver region, and indeed in all of Canada, for her effective advocacy work on behalf of immigrant people and visible minority people in Canada. I congratulate her on all the work that she has done over the years. She has asked about changing job barriers or eliminating job barriers to immigrant women in Canada. There are a number of steps that could be taken very quickly and very easily in order to get rid of some of those barriers.
One of the main things that needs to be done, and I think I referred to it in the comments I made earlier, is that we need to develop a comprehensive and universal program of language training for all immigrants and refugees in this country. If people do not have access to education and training in our official languages, it is impossible for them to integrate themselves and to take part in our communities and our society at large. That

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
program must have adequate training allowances for both men and women. A child care provision is absolutely necessary for immigrant women and refugee women to be able to participate in these programs. We know that this government has announced recently that it has been pleased to be, and the language used was "the killer of a national child care program". Any kind of universal program on language, must have a child care component in it, not only for women but for some men as well who are care givers to their children.
We would also need to find a way to reach out to immigrant women who are in job ghettos right now where they are being sometimes exploited because of their lack of language skills.
Another key component, I believe, would be an accreditation program for people who come to this country with foreign credentials so that we no longer see a situation where a woman may come from another area of the world who has been a medical doctor or in some other kind of profession and her credentials are not recognized by Canadians. We need a program accreditation of foreign credentials so that these professionals do not end up being the people who have to clean the floors in the hospital in order to tiy to put food on the table for their families.
Another area that needs to be addressed by this Parliament and is under review right now is the whole issue of employment equity. We need an employment equity program in this country that has targets, timetables and an effective mechanism for implementation.
Finally, I would add that the domestic workers program should be changed to eliminate any racist policies that are currently in effect in this country in our domestic workers program.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
I welcome the opportunity to speak in support of my hon. colleagues who have spoken from our side this afternoon, against today's motion. I think my colleagues have ably presented the facts and defended the record of the government in helping to retrain Canadian workers.
Consequently, I will then hopefully address a broader issue; the efforts that we have undertaken to establish a positive economic climate so that Canadians, including those who seek work, can expect secure and meaningful jobs in the future.
Canadians now know what is required to reduce unemployment. They want to return to an economic growth situation. This is exactly the goal that the government is pursuing.
Our policy framework is positioning Canada for renewed recovery this year in spite of the economic slowdown that has taken place around the world, especially in the United States of America, our largest export market.
Last week the International Monetary Fund predicted that Canada will have the strongest economic growth of any of the G-7 countries this year and in 1993. The OECD has made similar predictions as has the Asian Development Bank. I know the opposition is reluctant to hear and accept all this good news and try to help our country become more positive but it is true. Last week the International Monetary Fund made that prediction and it should be known by everybody.
I also want to remind the House of a comment made by IMF's research director at a news conference last month. According to a story in The Financial Post he said of Canada and our government policies: "More work needs to be done on the fiscal imbalance, but I think one would say there is a greater confidence concerning both past accomplishments and future actions than there is in several other industrialized countries and that should aid confidence and recovery in Canada".
There is an important point I want to make here. While pointing out the positive outlook for renewed economic growth I do not mean to downplay the real problems that face us in this country. Too many Canadians are out of work. There is anxiety about the threat of job loss by those who are working. Economic competence is low and, that is helped along by the doom and gloom spread around by some people.

The solution to these problems does not lie in the vague promises and partisan complaints that the opposition tends to offer as it has today. In particular, the solutions will not be found in the tragic formula of higher spending, higher taxes and higher deficits that is the clear record of both parties from across the floor, federally and provincially.
Instead, the solution lies in sticking to the policies that are setting the foundations for that renewed growth, as was confirmed by the IMF, and our prospects for that growth will be made even stronger as Canadians recognize the positive factors we worked so hard to put into place.
Let me remind the House of some of the economic developments that demonstrate why there is a good reason for renewed confidence in Canada. The commercial bank prime rate has dropped 7 percentage points since May 1990. Just today the Bank of Montreal has announced a further one quarter point cut in the prime rate to 7.5 per cent.
Mortgage rates have also fallen substantively. Just a few months ago the members opposite were carping and crying for lower interest rates and that was what we needed. Now we have lower interest rates but you never hear about them.
Those are the guys that got us 22 per cent.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Oh, yes, they were there when it was 22 per cent and inflation at 15 per cent. I well know. I experienced it as a small businessman.
Mortgage rates have fallen substantially. They are in the 9 per cent range for one year conventional mortgages compared to 14.25 per cent in 1990. For a $75,000 mortgage amortized over 25 years that is a saving of $273 a month or about one third of a family's mortgage costs.
We are talking all the time about getting more money back into the hands of consumers and raising consumer confidence. What could be better than that for many young and middle aged couples who have been carrying mortgages to have that kind of savings in mortgage costs?
Government Orders
Underlying this progress is a substantial drop in inflation. Inflation, the silent creeping killer of business and of confidence, has had a substantial drop.
The year after year increase in the Consumer Price Index this March was 1.6 per cent, one of the lowest levels since the early 1970s. Each of these factors represents the important progress in putting in place a strong foundation for renewed confidence, competitiveness and sustained growth. There we have it: lower interest rates, thus lower mortgage rates. We have a drop in inflation. All of these combined efforts are what have been asked for and what we have today in this country.
Lower mortgage rates and an easing of inflation and new house prices have improved housing affordability to one of the best levels in 10 years. We have taken additional action to further strengthen the prospects for the housing and construction sector. We have moved to reduce the down payment required for a CMHC insured mortgage to 5 per cent from the previous 10 per cent level. The real estate people in my riding certainly are lauding that move and are finding definite action in the real estate market due to that change in down payment.
In the February budget this government made it possible for homeowners to use funds in their RRSPs for home purchase. This one-year program, combined with the lower mortgage rates and lower requirements for CMHC mortgages, guarantees an already sputtering economy to really start moving along and spurring this economy on. Sales of existing homes have increased nearly 25 per cent in the first quarter compared to the last quarter of 1991. The housing market is so very important and that kind of increase is important to our economy. The housing market is responding to lower rates and we expect consumer spending to also respond in turn with a result that economic growth will begin to pick up as we carry on through this year.
Lower rates will also help the business sector improve balance to balance sheets. Cash flow will improve, boosting the ability of business to invest and to create many job opportunities. The opportunity for the retailer who has one store to add and to diversify and add another retail store to carry on taking advantage of the

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
consumer confidence is the kind of thing that happens and the kind of business that we need to see start up so that we hire more and more people.
Not only are we taking action, but we are taking the right action we believe to set the economy on track and bring down unemployment. It is action based on a basic fact of economic life. For a trade dependent nation like Canada jobs are maintained and new jobs are created only through a private sector that can successfully compete in the global marketplace.
Lower interest rates over the long term are the key to sustainable economic recovery on sustained economic recovery and a sustained job creation situation. Not only do they encourage consumer spending but they are essential for business to invest in new equipment and techniques needed to increase productivity and to pursue new opportunities and needs.
To get those interest rates down and, more important, to keep them down it is essential to curb inflation and inflation expectations. It is no accident that during the 1980s nations that maintained low inflation, Germany and Japan, also enjoyed the lowest interest rates. That is why we have taken real action against inflation. We have taken action by establishing firm and realistic inflation targets, by taking the lead in restraining government wages and salaries, and that is why we have passed legislation curbing parliamentary and Public Service wages.
We have taken the lead and look at what has followed across the country, how the provinces have taken the lead and the private sector now is taking the lead. The federal government took the very important lead that certainly contributed so much to keeping inflation in line.
We have also taken action by maintaining our commitment through concrete actions to set federal government finances on track and setting it toward a balanced budget by the mid-1990s despite the pressures of a weak economy. We have done that on the operational side.
Our commitment to inflation reduction and good fiscal management establishes the conditions needed to make our businesses and our workers better able to compete and succeed in the world marketplace. Our efforts are laying firm foundations for job creation and the sustained prosperity that flows from increased employment.
I should also like to remind the House that our competence is not just based on our success against inflation and lower interest rates. Canada will also reap the benefits of the structural reforms our government has put in place over the last eight years. These are reforms designed to reduce government interference in the marketplace, to boost businesses' ability to compete and respond to new opportunities. We deregulated the energy and transportation sectors. We have acted to reduce the size and increase the efficiency of government operations.
These structural reforms also include tax reform. For example, the GST eliminated the old manufacturers' sales tax that put our domestic businesses at a definite disadvantage. Our government has played a leadership role through the Canada-U.S.-
Cross-border shopping is increasing.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
I know they do not want to hear all this good news across the way. I am sure they do not want to hear all the good news from the government side so they want to try and stop us from speaking, -through the Canada-U.S. free trade agreement and the ongoing GATT talks to reduce the barriers to international trade on which our economy is dependent.
These reforms are very important though they have not been painless and we have had to think of what we have delivered.
Our reforms are delivering and I think there are bottom-line results. As The Globe and Mail said in an editorial recently, third party reference for my friends across the way: "Canada is in the early stages of an export led productivity driven economic boom with manufacturing in a feature role. Exports to the United States are already climbing. Last year's $91 billion U.S. total was a gain at almost 30 per cent in four years". It is good news stuff, good news that undoubtedly the opposition and certainly the author of this motion does not want to hear.
Economists at Wood Gundy forecast manufacturing productivity, after rising .4 per cent last year, will leap 8 per cent this year and 12 per cent the next with comparable gains and output. There we go, good positive stuff.
We proposed additional action in last February's budget to further encourage a return to economic growth and to enhance Canadian businesses' ability to compete internationally.
May 8, 1992

We announced that the personal income surtax will be cut by 1 per cent. We also introduced a series of measures to help Canada's manufacturing and processing sector to meet the challenge of fierce global competition.
This is very important to my area where the high capital intensive petrochemical industry is situated. The industry has asked and we have responded in the budget by reducing by two points to 21 per cent over the next two years the marginal tax rate for such companies.
The capital cost allowance is very important. Maybe the members opposite want to make light of this but it is certainly very important to many sectors: the petrochemical sector, the pulp and paper sector, sectors where there is substantive capital intensive building going on which provide jobs in Canada. We have taken and adjusted the capital cost allowance for manufacturing and processing equipment.
That is what they have asked for and certainly that is what we have delivered.
The province of Ontario has taken the lead and has adjusted it slightly to make it more attractive for capital investment in Canada.
We have made some very important moves. We have to do some more but we have made some important moves in that direction to attract foreign investment or investment like an ethylene plant which would cost close to $1 billion to build in Sarnia-Lambton.
We are also establishing the small business financing program. It is important to keep that engine of growth going.
They are all important steps to assist Canadian firms to compete successfully and to create new jobs. To pay for the net reduction in Canadians' tax burdens there will be substantial reduction in government spending. We will be reducing taxes by reducing spending and streamlining government. Canadians want government operations streamlined and we will reduce the demands on government revenues by about $7.3 billion over the next five years.
Let me reiterate that the measures we have taken, combined with an upturn in the U.S. economy, our major export market, are positioning Canada for renewed growth and for job creation as the year progresses. There
Government Orders
are already a number of very positive indications as we all know, those who sit in the House and read the newspapers and hear the news and hear what is said every day.
Canada's economic output, our gross domestic product, has moved up in both January and February, the first growth since last July. Retail trade grew for the fourth consecutive month. Manufacturing shipments rose 1.1 per cent in February, the first increase in six months.
Real exports averaged 2.3 per cent above the fourth quarter level in January and February.
The Conference Board index of business confidence rebounded 16.1 per cent in the first quarter after declines in the previous two quarters. It is at the highest level in over two years. These indications are in keeping with the outlook presented in the February budget by the Minister of Finance.
The growth would come slowly at first, accelerate in the second half of the year, and rise to 4.5 per cent for 1993.1 suppose the opposition shudders to hear we are going to have this great economic growth. It is coming along and the right things are being said and the right signals are being heard.
In conclusion, as a government we do not believe this is the time to change course. This is the time to appreciate the positive foundations for renewal that have been put in place and to ensure they are maintained.
We have put in place a series of measures that today offer the prospect of world leading growth, encouraged by dramatically lower inflation and very low interest rates. This is the environment we are creating for Canadians. For those with jobs, this translates into greater security and opportunity. For those who are seeking work, it means a chance to put their skills, especially the skills built up through the programs mentioned by my hon. colleagues earlier to work at long-term, stable, meaningful jobs through the kind of training and opportunity that should come forward with this economic renewal.
I want to thank the House for the opportunity to speak to this motion and of course I do not to accept in any way the motion that has been put forward. It is certainly not opportune and not in keeping with what is happening in

May 8, 1992
Government Orders
Canada today. I want to laud our government for the initiatives it has taken.

Madam Speaker, I would like to put together a few questions for the member if I can. However, I will put it in the proper context first.
The question I want to ask is based on the fact the member feels very strongly his government has put together a very good package of policy changes for the people of Canada. One particular policy he refers to of excellent vintage is the policy he called free trade.
In my hand I have a transcript of an interview that was done in the Business News by a potential presidential candidate in the United States. As you may well know, this individual does not come from the same party as I or the NDP. This man has so much money he could probably buy half of Canada.
I want to read into the record some of his thoughts because he talks about free trade. There is a debate, as you know, in the United States about the free trade agreement with Mexico. I am sure you will recall these words being spoken by other members in the House when we were debating free trade in 1987-1988. The question is this:
Can we negotiate a fair North American free trade agreement?
The answer by our very rich friend is this:
I am for fair free trade but you realize we have a very fragile situation as far as being able to pay our bills as a country.
