Now what does Mexico pay its people? A dollar an hour? What do we pay our factory workers here? Oh say, $17.50 an hour. Any health care in Mexico? Little or none. Any retirement? Little or none.
I called the who's who of American manufacturing and I said when would you build your next factory in the U.S. if this went through? They laughed. They said we would not. Then I decided the guys who put this agreement together must know something I do not know. So I called some of them and they said it would be disruptive but they say eventually it will stabilize itself, it is somewhere between 15 and 20 years.
The next question:
Is any kind of a free trade agreement with them even possible then?
The answer:
You would have to again bring the best people in the industry together, develop a plan to phase it in, work with Mexico, work with Canada, to phase it in. Even then you had better run pilot programs to make sure you do not have unanticipated adverse side effects that will really adversely impact on our economy. You say, well, my gosh,
Perot, how can you sell that to Mexico and to Canada? Pretty
simple, I can sell it to anybody. Do you know why? We are the
biggest customer in the world.
It sounds very familiar to what our friends on the government side have been saying about the free trade agreement. Those are the exact same words they used. A multi-billionaire in the United States who is running for president is saying the exact same thing that the Liberal Party said in 1988. We did not have the proper process in place and we were not prepared for the inevitability and the downside of free trade. The downside of free trade has been a loss so far of roughly 400,000 jobs, that is 22 per cent of our manufacturing base.
These members on the opposite side continue to give us the nonsense that it is a great policy and really working. We are in desperate shape in this country. A multi-billionaire in the United States is not exactly an individual who is slow. He is a neo-conservative, rightwing, and he still is smart enough to realize that a free trade agreement with a country like Mexico is going to kick the pants off him and is no different than the free trade agreement we signed with the United States.
I would like to ask the member this very simple question. If even a neo-Conservative can tell the difference between a bad agreement and a good agreement, how is it that the Conservatives across the floor who are not as far right wing cannot tell when we have been taken to the cleaners?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour

Madam Speaker, I thank my friend who appears to be dead set against the free trade agreement. I am a little surprised because it seems that his party is now kind of coming around where it is positive about maintaining the agreement. I think also he probably should know that in that same article Mr. Perot also said, when he talks negatively about the deal, that Canada ended up getting the better deal out of it with the United States. I think he forgot to mention that.
On this business of wages I would like to say that it is one that proves a point. If we talk about wages in Mexico, yes there is a wage difference but wages are only part of the total cost of producing goods and services. If wages were the only factor in the United States, all the businesses would have moved from Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Connecticut down to Alabama and Tennessee. It has not happened. It did not happen and it will not happen. There are a number of other very

important factors that go into the production of goods and services.
We all know that the free trade agreement is the right way to go. Even the United Steel Workers said in a recent document put out last October-and maybe we ought to bring you guys from the Liberal Party over to undoubtedly where this individual comes from-who said that their union rejected protectionism because Canada needs to export, stating withdrawal from the international economy is not a realistic alternative for Canada. The hon. member used to be involved in union work. I appreciate his comment because he is a friend and an interested member of Parliament. However, I do not want him to get offside on this free trade business with this rhetoric. Certainly free trade is important.
I will tell the hon. member about my own riding where refining and petrochemicals is tremendously important. Sixty-five per cent of what we produce in Sarnia-Lamb-ton is exported to the United States. It is very important that we are competitive. We had a five-year countdown on the FTA and we have asked to have it lowered even faster than that. It has meant a tremendous amount in the productivity cost situation of producing petrochemicals that we want to export to the United States so the free trade agreement is very important.
The free trade agreement has helped the province of Ontario and of course all Canada. As I stated earlier, our exports are up. Since the FTA came into effect, Canada's trade surplus with the United States went from approximately $13 billion to $18 billion in 1990. That is an increase of almost 40 per cent. The facts are there. Certainly there is some shake-out and there are some changes that are going to take place.
It is the dawning of a new era, I say to my hon. friend across the way, one of globalized international competitive trade.
As a country we have to be part of it or we are going to be set aside forever. We have made the decision that we have to be in there and be competitive. We can, as a country, be competitive for the most productive, highest standard of living in the country in all the industrialized world.

Madam Speaker, I suppose after listening to the speech given by my hon. friend from Sarnia-Lambton it would behove me to bring this Chamber back to earth. First, I would ask the indulgence of members of the House and viewers watching to exercise their imaginations along with me for a few moments.
Imagine, if you will, a government that comes to Ottawa. It is a right wing laissez-faire government committed to a totally free market economy. This commitment is carried to a fault.
Imagine, if you will, this government having close connections with big money and transnational and multinational corporations. So close are these connections that the government does not move without first consulting its big money friends who provide many elected members of the government with most of their campaign funds.
Imagine, if you will, that the government at the behest of its corporate friends pursues a policy of continental-ism so its friends can roam freely over the continent cannibalizing plants, closing plants and moving plants across the border.
Imagine, if you will, that this government, out of its commitment to a free market economy, pushes a policy of deregulation, privatization and ending orderly marketing through the destruction of marketing boards.
Imagine, if you will, that the government holds to a philosophy of survival of the fittest, leaving the provinces and municipalities to fend more and more for themselves.
In accordance with this philosophy, there is less help to the needy, less help to the jobless and less help to those seeking opportunity through retraining, the very subject now before this House.

Let us return to reality and here I ask the question: Does this government remind us of the government which has been governing Canada for almost the last eight years? I think it does.
We know that the current government is right wing, pursuing a corporate agenda. This government certainly has close ties to international big business and it has implemented a so-called free trade agreement to move forward its continentalist policies. Its deregulation and privatization are well known, as are its policies which threaten our supply management system and, by extension, our dairy, poultry and egg industries.
We all know about this government's cuts in transfer payments to the provinces which make it almost impossible for the provinces to provide their customary support of medicare and education. Medicare, as we all know, is at risk and in my province of Manitoba the University of Manitoba tuition fees have been raised 16 per cent.
How about job training, the focus of today's debate? The government says it is committed to job training, R and D, education and the like. I wish it were true but it is not and here are some of the facts.
If we start with the benchmark year of 1989-90-that is when Bill C-21 was brought in-we see two things that have happened.
First, a training fund under unemployment insurance was started, and in the current year, $500 million will be spent. That sounds like a lot of money. It sounds good, but not a nickel will come from this government, not one red cent. Sixty per cent will be contributed by employers and 40 per cent by employees.
Does that mean that the government spends no money at all on training? No, of course not. This is part number two. About $1,345 billion is spent under the Canadian Jobs Strategy program. That figure represents a cut, a reduction of $217 million since the year 1989-90. I believe that is a terrible indictment of this government. But it is hardly surprising because this government is so busy pursuing its corporate agenda that it has forgotten people who are looking for opportunity and certainly job training represents opportunity.
I was shocked by an answer given by the Prime Minister to my leader in the House on Wednesday of this week. My leader was pointing out the critical problems facing our big cities-unemployment, food banks, violent crime, drugs, the homeless-and he described this week's Toronto riots as an SOS for the government. Well, what did the right hon. Prime Minister say? First he tried to play down the problems facing our cities. And then the Prime Minister said this, and I quote from Hansard:
The Conference Board reported this morning, for example, that business confidence is up to its highest level in two years. The economic turnaround continues. So there will be both economic and social improvements.
What has that got to do with the civil unrest we saw in Toronto? What has it got to do with the crises of our cities? Absolutely nothing.
It shows how out of touch this Prime Minister is. It reveals that he is so wrapped up in his government's corporate agenda, so preoccupied with helping its friends, that he has totally forgotten about disadvantaged Canadians.
A million and a half Canadians are unemployed. That is 11 per cent of the work force. These Canadians want more educational opportunities, more training and retraining. These Canadians, especially the young, the unemployed, look to this government not for handouts but for leadership to put the economy on a sound footing and for opportunities to enter the economy and enjoy rewarding careers. They are not getting it from this government.
And the only thing they hear is a Bay Street message from the Prime Minister. That is appalling. But sad to say, it is consistent with what George Bush has been telling the people of the inner cities of America. After the Los Angeles riots Mr. Bush more or less said: "Don't expect any help from your federal government; you are on your own".
Not only does the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Canada boat together, they read and take their cues from the very same Conservative handbook.

I fully support the motion before us today. Canadians have lost confidence in this government and, to quote a part of the motion, "because of its abject failure to provide job training and retraining initiatives".
This government has broken a long-standing social contract in Canada. It has refused to accept its responsibilities. That is why I believe that Canadians will turf this government out at the very first opportunity, namely the next election.

that Bill C-332, an act to amend the Divorce Act (granting of access to, or custody of, a child to a grandparent), be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Madam Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity of carrying on with this bill which I feel is very important to a great number of Canadians. It was originated by Mrs. Nancy Woolridge of the Canadian Grandparents Rights League in my riding, who is very concerned along with many other grandparents across the country about the fact that they could lose access to their grandchildren, primarily through divorce but also at other times.
My mind goes back a couple of years ago when I was in the small town of Chemainus on Vancouver Island walking along the street and I looked into a store and there was T-shirt in the window that said something to the effect: "If I had known having grandchildren was so much fun I would have had them first". I think many grandparents have experienced that the joys of being grandparents can be very great. I think it is part of the richest and deepest relationship human beings can have with one another, between grandparents and the grandchild.
Unfortunately in our modem world we do have some things that we have to look at. The fact is that we do have the nuclear family. We no longer have mom and dad, grandma and grandpa, uncles, aunts in the neighbourhood but they are often scattered all over the country.
Also, we have many broken families where there may be a single parent with children. There may be families which are blended families that we have to deal with.
As a result there are many disrupted lives that need healing. They need something that can hold them together in this very complicated and stressful world in which we live. It is particularly the children who suffer
Private Members' Business
when a marriage breaks up. They are the innocent parties. They usually have nothing to do with a marriage and yet they are the ones who are the least able to cope with the problems that the divorce effects.
With these defenseless children there are some tremendous resources that are available. These are primarily the grandparents that are involved. The grandparents can be very useful for many reasons.
The problem we have today and the reason for introducing this bill is that the present legislation says that the grandparents have no legal access to the grandchildren. In other words, if I as a grandparent wanted to see a grandson who was living with a a former daughter-in-law I may have to go to court unless there is an agreement made. I would have to go to court to gain access to that child who would be very important to me. You say: "Let them go to court and solve the problem". This could be tremendously expensive. It can be time consuming. I have had cases where grandparents have spent over $10,000 in court to gain access to these children in the adversarial system that we have in our court system. It is not conducive to harmonious relationships. For all of us at times like this our prime concern is with the children and their best welfare.
What we intend to do in the new legislation in Bill C-332 is to state very simply "a person other than a spouse or grandparent". In other words, we are saying that a grandparent would be the equivalent of a spouse in having access to a child and may not make application under subclause 1 or 2 without leave of the court.
Under clause 1(5), "unless a court orders otherwise, the spouse or grandparent who is granted access to a child of the marriage has a right to make inquiries and be given information as to the health, education and welfare of the child". The explanatory note in this bill is quite clear. This bill would provide "that a person wishing to make an application under the Divorce Act to be granted custody of any of his or her grandchildren shall not be required to obtain leave of the court to make such an application". The bill would also provide that "a person who is granted access to any of his or her grandchildren shall have the right to make inquiries and to be given information as to the health, education and welfare of the child". In other words that grandparent

May 8, 1992

could have full access to any information that was available to the child and this is very, very important.
Why should the grandparents be involved? We have parents who are responsible. There are some very important things that grandparents can contribute to the security of the child. First of all, grandparents can give a real sense of security and continuity of life to the young people. Their parents have broken up, perhaps they are living with different people, their homes may be changed and very often the fact that grandparents are a constant, that they have not gone away and left them, they have not changed, it gives a real sense of continuity. It also provides the child with a sense that life goes on. We were grandchildren, we were parents, we have grandparents. It produces that continuity of life, that we are not just isolated in the world in which we live.
The author of the book Roots showed a real example of the need to go back and to see where we came from, that we are a continuity, a part of a continuity. Grandparents are in a splendid position to produce the feeling of being wanted. I think very often that grandparents can give the child a sense that there is no alienation, that they can in other words work around the alienation that may be present between the parents. The grandparents may not necessarily be involved in that. They can produce in that child a real sense of being needed and wanted.
Grandparents can produce more of an unconditional love. They are not responsible for the marriage breakup. They are not directly responsible in many cases for the actual welfare of the children. They can come in as somebody who can love them no matter what kind of mischief they have been into, how they are acting as a result of the break-up of the marriage.
There is another very practical thing that grandparents can provide. Statistics have shown us that the age group between 55 and 65 has more disposable income than any other group in our society. This is also important to children, that they can perhaps provide them with the material things, clothing, perhaps vacations, this type of thing, that a single parent could not provide for them.
In that area they often have more tact. The other children are out of the home and they can provide the time that is necessary. They can provide understanding, patience, and hopefully we grandparents are more relaxed about our role. We recognize that a lot of these little things that concern parents were perhaps not that
important. We have been through it once already with our own children and realize that the things we thought were important with our kids are not necessarily as important when we are looking at our grandchildren. I think it is important that we look at these things.
It is very significant that grandparents seem to have a real natural regard and concern for grandchildren. This whole subject was debated in the Alberta legislature. I would like to read from its Hansard regarding it. Mrs. Hughes was speaking. She quoted a study by Jim Gladstone at the University of Guelph. He conducted a study in 1986 that reinforced the importance of grandparents to grandchildren.
That report concluded that when marriages break down grandmothers have more contact with their grandchildren than before the breakdown. Gladstone believes that this means that grandparents have an innate tendency to respond to the needs and emotional upheaval of their children. Previous research on children of divorce has suggested that young children have very little opportunity to talk about the break-up.
Gladstone believes that through the child's unique relationship with the grandparents they can obtain the kind of counselling, comfort, reassurance that they need, providing they have access and continuous access. Therefore, there is a necessity for creative legislation that protects access for both grandparents and the non-custodial spouse. I think that is very significant.
The other thing that grandparents can provide is the idea of modelling and teaching. I know that with my own grandchildren I can teach them a lot of things about nature and life that perhaps my son and daughter could not have.
Traditionally we look at various cultures around the world. We see the importance of grandparents in raising children. With the B.C. Indians, for example, traditionally the grandparents raised the young people. Also in the Chinese culture and many other cultures around the world it is very important.
In the debate in the Alberta legislature, Mr. Shrake as reported at page 562 of the April Hansard, said: "I guess throughout the history of mankind the societies throughout Asia, Europe, and North America, all of them had concern for the children. Throughout all of these societies, whether it is a modem society, or the aboriginal
May 8, 1992

people, there was always a place in the old days where the elders were respected, the elders helped train the children, they passed on tradition, culture, heritage, and these little things. It went on way beyond that. It went to the point of giving the feeling of security, the feeling of love and warmth". There is more but we will not take the time to read it.
We can see that grandparents have a great deal to contribute to the life of these children of broken marriages.
We need also to look at precedents in legislation. For example, all 50 states in the United States have similar types of legislation. In Canada, Quebec in article 659 has dealt with this item and Ontario in article 59(4).
I would just like to quote the Quebec article. It says: "In no case may the father or mother without serious cause place obstacles to personal relationship between the child and his grandparents". I think that is very significant. This is in Quebec civil law. It is the only province thus far that has enshrined it into law.
We could give many practical examples of how grandparents have been obstructed through the court system from contacting children when they could have been a very positive force. The Grandparents' Rights Association has many documented cases. Again because of time we are not going to go into them today. I think in many cases it is a personal tragedy for the grandparents but more important for the grandchildren who are being deprived of this important asset.
Therefore I think it is important that we have legal protection for our grandchildren. We recognize that all grandparents are not beneficial to grandchildren. There are times when they should not have direct access. This can still be established by the court. We have not changed anything about that.
This would be a very positive step toward protection and development of the child. It is something that lawmakers in Canada could contribute to. I am asking the government in any consideration of future legislation to consider including the rights of grandparents in a fair and legitimate manner.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to rise and speak on this bill as well. Although the appearance of grey hair may indicate that I am a grandfather, that is not the case unless my kids have a surprise for me when I get home.
I still feel I should rise and speak on this particular bill.
I must confess that the bill is well aimed. Its direction is important. Given our changing society and the number of marriage breakdowns which are occurring, there is no question that grandparents can fulfil a very important role in giving a child stability and ensuring a well developed and well rounded individual.
We have seen in some of the information that has been distributed some very tragic stories of what has occurred to children. My children have had the benefit of grandparents on both sides of the family, although now three out of the four are deceased. There is a closer relationship with the one remaining grandparent. They go to her on many occasions to discuss issues. Two of my children are away from home and they cany on a writing relationship with their remaining grandmother to keep that link. It is important to have that base and that continuity. As the member has already said there is an important element and an important role to be played.
My problem with this particular legislation is that I am also a lawyer. When I start analysing the bill, I have some hesitation with the way that the member opposite has gone about trying to include grandparents' rights in the divorce legislation. It strikes me that there may be a better way to do it than to give grandparents their rights in this fashion.
There is potential for abuse. There is potential for problems. For that reason I would like to see it structured slightly differently. The Quebec legal code suggestion and wording in the Divorce Act similar to the Quebec legislation might serve the purpose rather than add spouses and grandparents to the legislation as far as rights to apply for custody or to deal with information involving children.
We have to face one certain reality, that is the primary interest is with the child. Here goes the grandfather and grandmother vote, but they are not as important, quite frankly. It is the child who is important.

Madam Speaker, I would just like to rise very briefly to endorse the bill before the House, certainly the intent of the bill. I cannot speak for all of my party. This is Private Members' Hour. However, the bill certainly has my support. I suspect it has a great deal of sympathy and support throughout the House of Commons.
The member is to be congratulated for bringing this issue forward. It is one in this era of family breakup that is becoming increasingly important and one which needs to be the focus of public attention. Grandparents themselves generally form very close bonds with their grandchildren, and those bonds should not be among the victims of a family break-up.
It seems to me veiy important that the relationship between grandchildren and their grandparents be encouraged, developed and supported. As the member has indicated often in a period of family break-up the relationship with the grandparents is a very significant and important one in retaining the necessary support systems for the children in a parental breakup. For the grandparents to be able to continue to have a place in the lives of their grandchildren is very critical for the children.
I can think of a relationship that is close to me. It concerns a single mother. The grandmother of her children had developed that bond and that relationship even though there had been no marriage and the pair really did not live together for very long after the birth of the children.
Yet so strong was the bond developed between the grandmother and granddaughter and grandson that when eventually the mother married someone else, the grandmother was an honoured guest at the wedding. She also played a very important part in helping the children adjust to the new situation, to accept it and to learn to grow within it. It was very touching and very important. I think there are many similar situations which need to

have the support of Parliament and the support of the public.
The relationship for grandparents is very important so that they have the opportunity to continue to develop and build the relationship. It is very much part of our life and one which, in this industrial and urban society, is too often reduced and cut short with or without problems among the children.
It is a bill that has my support. I would urge the House to adopt it. I know under the rules that it is probably not likely but I hope the hon. member will continue his battle on this. He can count on my support and I am sure that of many other members of the House.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to join in the debate this afternoon. I congratulate the hon. member for Delta for raising this important matter and encouraging debate on it. The hon. member for Delta has established the reputation here in the House of caring and compassion for which he is well known and well respected in the Delta-Tsawwassen area of British Columbia.
This bill reflects that caring for individuals and concern for people. It is well reflected in Bill C-332 which proposes some amendments to the Divorce Act to improve grandparent access.
As you are aware, Madam Speaker, the Divorce Act is legislation that governs divorce but also deals with the issues considered corollary to divorce, namely child support and custody and spousal support.
I would like to remind members that in June 1986 amendments to the Divorce Act were implemented that introduced revisions and terminology and substance to almost every section of the former legislation. The reforms had three objectives. First, it makes divorce less adversarial while increasing chances for reconciliation. Second, it recognizes provincial responsibilities and provides for a process of divorce which would operate with as few complications and duplications as possible. Third, it provides a more humane and fairer resolution of the consequences of divorce in today's society specifically with respect to custody and economic outcomes. It is this
Private Members' Business
third objective that I would like to focus on because I think it relates directly to Bill C-332.
Unfortunately I am all too aware that in some cases grandparents are being denied contact with their grandchildren after a divorce. I appreciate that this is a very painful experience for both the children and their grandparents. While I hope this kind of situation is limited to unusual cases where divorce has been especially bitter, I know that it occurs frequently enough to warrant the formation of support groups as was mentioned by the hon. member for Delta.
There are organizations such as the Canadian Grandparents' Rights Association and Grandparents Requesting Access and Dignity which help grandparents cope in these situations and do an admirable job. Some of these groups have undertaken to lobby for legislative change. I am aware that Bill C-332 attempts to respond to some of the concerns that these groups have raised.
I think it is important to first review the provisions of the current Divorce Act. As a result of the 1986 amendments the Divorce Act confers a broad discretionary jurisdiction on the court to make a custody or access order. Application may be brought by either or both spouses or former spouses or by any other person with leave of the court. This means that although the issue of grandparent access is not specifically addressed in the current Divorce Act, third parties including grandparents may now seek leave to make custody and/or access application.
In addition the Divorce Act now provides that the sole criteria for the making of an order of custody and access is: "The best interests of the child of the marriage as determined by reference to the conditions, means, needs, and other circumstances of the child".
In other words grandparents can apply for leave to make a custody or access application. I believe since the sole criteria is the best interests of the child, grandparents who have a real and close relationship with their grandchildren can already request and presumably get a court order granting them access consistent with the best interests of the child.
I would like to note that through the efforts of a number of groups we have just mentioned, through the hon. member for Delta, interested and concerned grandparents and supporters of this type of legislation across the country, the Minister of Justice has announced a major review of judicial family law for the purpose of improving its fairness and effectiveness. I understand this review is currently going on and that one part of this project is the review of the present legal regime governing child custody and access.

May 8, 1992
Private Members' Business
Many issues have been identified and the Department of Justice will be consulting soon with interested groups. It is expected these consultations will solicit views that will help determine which issues should be addressed and provide guidance as to the nature of alternatives that should be pursued.
For example, some non-legislative options such as research, judicial education, parenting education, and improved counselling and mediation services have been identified that could address some of the issues and problems associated with access.
There are also different legislative approaches to consider. Family law is an overlapping jurisdiction and provincial statutes provide for the granting of custody and support during the subsistence of a spousal relationship and situations where there has been cohabitation without marriage.
I understand there have been some suggestions to consider provisions similar to article 659 of the Quebec Civil Code which statutorily recognizes that in no case may the father or the mother without serious cause place obstacles to personal relationships between the child and its grandparents. This is existing legislation in Quebec.
Several American states have concluded that new terminology and new approaches are required to deal
with custody and access issues. I am told that the Department of Justice is currently examining some of these alternatives and developing new proposals of its own.
To me it seems sensible to look at this issue of grandparent access within the context of a more general reform approach and I will encourage the Minister of Justice in her efforts to do so.
I again want to congratulate the member for Delta for his concern, his response to the concerns of his constituents, and many of our constituents across Canada in raising this important issue.
